In general terms, the Kimberley is like a great unopened box of treasures.

The biggest disadvantage the Kimberley has in terms of secondary industrial development is the cost of power. That is the major hurdle for the development of industry in the Kimberley. The cost of power is the major disadvantage that Western Australia in general faces when development is considered, because the cost of power in Western Australia is higher than it is in any other part of the country. In 1995-96 the nominal price per kilowatt-hour of electricity for commercial use in Western Australia was 10.72c. Unfortunately, that has increased since then. By contrast, around the rest of the country in 1995-96 the average cost of power was 8.06c per kilowatt-hour, and that has since come down. So Western Australia does have a disadvantage in terms of the cost of power.

As I said, the Kimberley has enormous potential in terms of mineral development and mining. The mining potential of the Kimber ley could be transformed by access to cheaper power. For example, at the moment the Kimberley mining industry contributes something like $485 million per year to the regional economy. The outlook for the industry is good, with Western Metals expanding operations in the area by opening up one of the world's largest zinc mines. The Pillara project, which is also a lead and zinc project, will bring into world markets very large amounts of lead and zinc. There is also one of the world's largest bauxite deposits on the Mitchell Plateau, but at the present time it is uneconomic to mine that bauxite deposit because of the cost of power. The process involved in converting bauxite to aluminium demands huge amounts of electricity, for which reason aluminium is sometimes described as `solid electricity'. For the mining industry, for the benefit of people in the towns in the Kimberley, for the potential development of tourist resorts and, in general, to enhance the lifestyle of the people in the Kimberley, the provision of cheap power will make an enormous difference to the cost economics of projects in that area.

For the benefit of the Senate, I would like to outline some details of the proposed Derby hydropower project. A proposal has been put forward to harness the tidal power of the Kimberley. The Kimberley has some of the very highest tides in the world, reaching 11 or 12 metres. It is proposed to use the rise and fall of the tides in the Kimberley to generate hydro-electricity which would then be distributed around the Kimberley by a conventional grid.

The location for this proposal, as I have said, is at Derby, which is the old regional service town of the West Kimberley, although it has now perhaps been somewhat eclipsed by Broome. The area around Derby is one of tidal flats. In Doctors Creek, it is proposed to put in a hydropower facility which will produce up to 48 megawatts of electricity output. A new company, Derby HydroPower Pty Ltd, is undertaking studies and working to gain the necessary approvals from the EPA and from the government in Western Australia.

Tidal power has many advantages. It is a clean source of energy. It is renewable energy, which I am sure would meet with the approval of my colleague Senator Brown if he were here listening to this. There being no pollution, the use of tidal power helps meet Australia's greenhouse emission commitments.

The tidal power station proposed for Derby is designed to have an operational life of 120 years. As time goes on, the price of electricity produced from this facility will get cheaper and cheaper because, apart from the capital cost of building the facility, tidal power generation costs are immune to such things as Middle East crises, increases in the price of oil, or other factors such as concerns about the use of uranium in nuclear power, which might mean that such a means of generating electricity could in time be unacceptable to the community.

Two options exist, I am told, for the proposed hydropower project in Derby in Doctors Creek: one, a so-called double basin option; and the other, a twin basin option. The location of this project is about 12 kilometres from Derby where there are two tidal creeks in the mangroves. In the double basin option, barrages will be built across the mouths of both creeks to control the water levels; sluice gates will allow the tide to run into the west creek, which is the high basin; and in the east creek, which is the low basin, water will only drain out at low tide. Turbines, to be located in the channel between the two basins, will be driven by water flowing from the high basin to the low basin. So there will be a continuous renewable source of energy providing power to the Kimberley area.

Obviously, tides rise and fall. During the neap tides, which will occur about two days each fortnight, power output will be reduced. To meet consumer demand and provide security for supply, it is proposed to provide supplementary thermal electricity generation in various locations around the Kimberley from traditional methods such as the use of diesel and other hydrocarbon fuels. But this will only be used to supplement the electricity produced from the Derby hydropower project.

The potential of this project is enormous because generating electricity from the tides at Derby, as I have said, will provide non-polluting reliable power, replacing the need for diesel generation or the use of other hydrocarbon burning fuels. It will allow for stable electricity prices at a low level. And, most importantly perhaps, it will help Australia meet its greenhouse commitments, because the use of the Derby hydropower project will mean a reduction of some 150,000 tonnes in CO2 emissions each year from powerhouse generation in the Kimberley alone.

One of the greatest benefits for the Kimberley from the development of a hydropower project will be the ability to establish a Kimberley grid. That will mean that, instead of small electricity stations running on diesel in the mines and towns of the Kimberley, a grid can be established which would cover the areas from Broome to Fitzroy Crossing, the Western Metals new mine at Pillara and any other new developments which occur in the area.

Western Power has, at the present time, asked for submissions on how the Kimberley power system might be improved, and it has certainly shown a great deal of interest in the prospect of very cheap hydropower from the Derby hydropower project. Of course, as I have said, there is the Mitchell Plateau bauxite deposit, which is one of the largest deposits in the world. Currently, it is simply not feasible to even consider developing those deposits. But, with a similar hydro scheme on one of the fiord-like gorges which form the Kimberley coast further north of Derby, the possibility of developing Mitchell Plateau bauxite becomes quite realistic—and not just a matter of turning it into alumina, but perhaps processing it all the way to aluminium.

Essentially, as I have said, aluminium is regarded as solid electricity, and the bauxite which we process in Australia into alumina is exported to countries like Norway and Canada; there it is further processed because those countries have cheap power. This project would bring to Australia electricity of comparative price to that in Norway and Canada where it is also generated by hydro electricity.

The Derby hydropower proposal is a very visionary scheme which will make use of one of Australia's greatest renewable energy resources—that being the huge tides on the Kimberley coast of Western Australia. The establishment of hydropower will bring extremely cheap electricity to the Kimberley; it will open up the region for development, which will transform the Kimberley; and it will also contribute to Australia's greenhouse emission reduction targets.

In conclusion, the Derby hydropower project has applied to be considered for a funding grant under the renewable energy showcase initiative, to which the coalition government has committed $10.5 million. I would put on record the fact that I believe this project would certainly be worthy of being awarded showcase funding. I certainly endorse the Derby hydropower's application for such funding because, as I have said, this is a very exciting and visionary project which will transform that area of the far north-west of Australia.

subdebateinfo.title: Human Rights: 50th Anniversary of Universal Declaration of Human Rights

talk.start.para: —As all honourable senators will know, tomorrow, 10 December 1998, marks the 50th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. This declaration, which probably has to be the most important document written this century, is accepted now by 182 countries. So to celebrate that anniversary, I think we would do well to remember the declaration's preamble, which says, in part:

speech.para: . . . recognition of the equal and inalienable rights of all members of the human family is the foundation of freedom, justice, and peace in the world.

There is no doubt that responsible governments should play a lead role in ensuring everyone has equal access to programs and services which promote and protect their human rights. In the absence of a constitutionally enshrined or federally legislated Bill of Rights—and, of course, we do not have one—human rights rely on a range of factors such as law reform, policy development and administration, the development of common law and, of course, proper levels of funding. These are the means through which we meet all our obligations not only under the Universal Declaration of Human Rights but also under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights.

Human rights are based on and are enshrined in international law. I think it would be true to say that most Australians are committed to social justice principles and human rights. Certainly the Democrats are. Such principles include: genuine consultation with members of the community on decisions which affect their lives; equity and fairness in the distribution of resources, especially for those members of the community most in need, including indigenous peoples, refugees and newly arrived migrants; improved accountability of decision makers; greater access to services and economic resources for improving quality of life; full and equal opportunity for all people to participate in decision making which affects all our lives; and the promotion and protection of all of our rights.

But the concept of human rights protection is not just about our domestic application of internationally agreed standards. Human rights are also fundamental to international security. Governments which disregard the rights of their own citizens will not progress as a society in any of the areas associated with human advancement—including social cohesion, including economic development, and including regional security. This became an issue recently at the APEC forum.

The sight of Australia trying to keep trade liberalisation on the top of the agenda while the world was preoccupied with the democratisation of the Asian region and the negative fallout from the Asian economic crisis was less than pleasing to many of us. It captured well the link between human rights, trade and development issues. It captured well the government's inability to deal with that. It also clearly demonstrated to the government that human rights protections are not a western concept and never have been—human rights are truly universal.

To insist that there is no place for discussing human rights in any sort of negotiation is both morally and tactically wrong. Respect for human rights should be a starting point for any negotiation. Apart from the overriding moral imperative, failure to take human rights into consideration during any negotiation will eventually backfire, as we have seen so dramatically in our region over the last 18 months. It leads only to instability and violence.

It is clear that the ability of nations to protect human rights effectively depends on the strength of its public institutions, a representative legislature and accountable executive government, an independent judiciary, and a distinct role between civil police services and the military. Thank goodness in Australia we have that. A vigorous civil society is another important element in the creation and maintenance of a culture of human rights. So is the right to self-determination of all peoples and the commitment of governments to supporting that outcome.

Governments working together with the United Nations, taking a key and active role in the bodies of the United Nations, including the International Labour Organisation, are continually signing onto and ratifying human rights conventions and encouraging in practical ways other nations to do likewise. It is only in practical and effective efforts to promote and protect human rights that a government can demonstrate a real commitment to the welfare of individuals and society as a whole.

The Human Rights Subcommittee of the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee, of which I hope to be a member this time—I have been in the past—completed only quite recently its report into the promotion of human rights in our region. We concluded that while human rights protections were improving, there still needed to be a great deal of work done in this area. Australia, because of our relative size, influence and international reputation, has a key role to play in the promotion of human rights in our region. The `people's struggle' movements we are currently witnessing are calling out for our support and assistance. We should not resile from offering that to them, nor from entering into dialogue with members from the opposition parties. That is something we must do. We have not done enough in the past and we must do it.

But strengthening Australia's credibility as a promoter of human rights in the region requires a coordinated effort and a great level of commitment that certain sections of the coalition government do not appear to have. The government also needs to demonstrate that it is prepared to collaborate with other nations' governments, opposition leaders and non-government organisations to achieve the ends that we want to achieve. The minister refers to a hectoring approach to others' foreign policy, but I believe that without persistent perusal of these objects nothing will change. We have to be loud, as well as being soft.

Australia has decreased emphasis on multilateral forums for advancement of human rights to bilateral dialogue, as evidenced in its move to bilateral dialogue with China and Indonesia. For bilateralism to be a useful tool in the advancement of human rights, that dialogue must also be transparent and accountable. Those two things are absent from the model advanced by Australia at the moment. This dialogue is not pursued with public resolutions condemning China's human rights dialogue. Indeed, the government does not even circulate details of visiting dignitaries' itineraries, in case they are greeted by protesters.

Because of that, it is the central issue of the universality of human rights—the notion that human rights are a western concept. Implicit in this construct is that somehow poorer countries cannot afford human rights protections. So we see culture, wealth and political ideology mitigating the strength of international human rights standards. Of course that is not the case. Of course human rights are universal, and of course everyone is now coming to agree with that. These challenges to the universality of human rights stand in the way of the confrontation of the fundamentals of human rights—the impact that the violation of human rights has on the ordinary citizens throughout the world but particularly in our region at the moment.

As we approach the 50th year of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights we should examine the interaction between all of these things. Is there a correlation between a nation's wealth and human rights? Are social and economic rights of greater or equal importance to civil and political rights? Are `economic reasons' grounds for defence against violation of the standards enshrined in the declaration? Obviously, the answer to all of those questions is no. The 50th anniversary is time to defend and reassert the primacy of the foundations of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights—universality and indivisibility. We must remember that the declaration did not emerge from wealthy and prosperous nations alone; it emerged from the horrors of World War II and the ravages of the Great Depression.

These ideals—the right to recognition as a person before the law without discrimination; the right to freedom from arbitrary arrest, detention and exile; the right to fair and public hearings by independent and impartial tribunals; the right to the presumption of innocence until proven guilty; the right to competent and independent representation; the right of appeal—were forged from desperate times. They constitute the framework for the rule of law, and that is a precondition for any civil society.

More broadly, the universality of human rights means practices like torture can never, never be condoned. There is no tradition which can justify the degradation of another human being. There is no political system licensed to indiscriminately kill. There is no religion whose vocation justifies summary justice. There is no culture, no particular historical event, no economic turmoil which may be deemed sufficient reason to deprive anyone of their human dignity.

So what about our own government's record? Since the coalition came to office in March 1996, they have slashed spending on a whole range of areas that impact on human rights. The coalition government has severely damaged Australia's international reputation for upholding human rights. They have downgraded their commitment to human rights' forums, particularly at the United Nations, and across a range of social services and policy areas. These include in the areas of social justice and equality: indigenous affairs, the status of women, access to justice, higher education, legal aid, migration, social security, employment, young people and health. That is ironic, given that the majority of Australians care very deeply about human rights.

Australians want the government to apologise to our indigenous peoples for the wrongs of the past. Despite the Prime Minister's commitment to reconciliation, which we are very pleased about, without an apology, nothing will be progressed. In the search for peace and reconciliation, both sides have to give. In 1998, this is a shameful position.

On the eve of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights 50th anniversary we should be thinking about these things. We should be considering where we want Australia to go over the next 50 years. I hope we want Australia to become a more humane society and to become some place that looks after and stands up for the human rights of others. This is a region that really needs that to happen, and we should again become a leader.

talk.start.para: —I rise once again to speak on the need for drug law reform in Australia. Before I begin, I would like to congratulate Senator Vanstone for her commitment to law enforcement in this area. On Tuesday, the Australian Federal Police captured a record size shipment of cocaine, with an estimated street value of $50 million. In anyone's language, that is certainly a large amount of money and a large amount of cocaine. However, this is a victory tinged with irony given facts that have come to light in recent weeks.

speech.para: A federal government survey into trends in drug use, released late last month, revealed a sixfold rise in cocaine use amongst drug users in Sydney. Researchers were told that cocaine is now readily available and prices have dropped significantly. One-hit caps are being sold for only $50. Last year a cap would have cost $80 and three years ago they were not reported to be available at all. The Australian newspaper reported on 27 November:

. . . cheaper and purer cocaine is flooding Sydney, where it is being sold like heroin, breaking into new markets in the western suburbs where cocaine use is just as common as in the more affluent eastern suburbs.

Clearly, the supply of cocaine to this country has been dramatically increasing over the past couple of years, despite this government's best efforts at law enforcement. The recent seizure of one shipment of cocaine, while is to be applauded, represents a mere drop in the bucket when we consider the relative increase in supply over the last few years.

So, while I congratulate Senator Vanstone, I note in question time yesterday that she claimed that the seizure indicated the government was `smashing transnational organised crime groups'. I certainly hope so, but I do doubt it. Senator Vanstone also said yesterday that the seizure sent a message to drug syndicates. Unfortunately, the dramatic increase in demand for cocaine in this country would be sending them another more financially compelling message.

Despite this government's law enforcement strategies, the incidence of drug use in Australia has continued to rise rapidly. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 27 November warned that Sydney is facing `a new wave of health, crime and social problems' as a direct result of increased cocaine use. Dr Darke, a senior lecturer with the National Drug and Alcohol Research Centre, has explained some of the reasons why cocaine is likely to provoke such problems. He said:

It is directly toxic to the heart and vascular systems and, unlike heroin, has a direct toxicity to the brain. There is a very strong association with serious psychiatric disturbances, such as paranoid psychosis. It has major implications for public order because it's a stimulant drug and people get wired up. You get a lot more violence.

The police commander of the Sydney eastern region agrees with Dr Darke that the incidence of cocaine use has increased dramatically. Obviously, efforts by this government to stem the flow of drugs into the country have enjoyed limited success. Unless something is done to address the demand side of the problem, future efforts to limit supply will continue to be constantly undermined.

The health problems associated with increased cocaine use will ultimately have widespread implications for the broader Australian community. The Australian article of 27 November compared the current situation in Australia with similar circumstances experienced abroad. It revealed:
. . . in Vancouver, where cocaine replaced heroin as the drug of choice among injecting users, the prevalence of HIV rose from two per cent to 15 per cent between 1994 and 1997.

Cocaine's short-lived effects mean that users have to inject far more frequently than heroin users, increasing the risk of spreading AIDS and other diseases like hepatitis C and B. These diseases are easily communicable to members of the non-using community.

These increases in cocaine use indicate that this government's policies have failed to put a dent in the supply side of the drug problem in Australia. The increasing incidence of drug use among young people in particular has by no means been arrested. This government needs to accept that its law enforcement policies are failing on the whole, despite a few isolated and well-publicised successes. The only way to arrest increasing drug use is to alter the approach to focus on the demand side of the problem. We need to look at why more and more of our young people are turning to drugs. In addition, the government needs to provide more funding to treatment facilities that are struggling to cope with increasing numbers of patients.

Senator Vanstone keeps talking about her government's so-called balanced Tough on Drugs strategy, but it seems this concept of equity does not extend to treatment services for users. The Tough on Drugs strategy has allocated $150 million over four years for law enforcement and Customs operations designed to address the supply side of the problem. Only $100 million has been allocated for treatment services. The funding allocated for treatment and prevention strategies together is only $117.5 million, compared with $150 million for the supply side strategies.

The government's emphasis is obviously still centred around law enforcement strategies, despite ongoing evidence that this is not the most effective approach. As I have previously said in this place, there must be a balance between law enforcement and treatment facilities. We must have more money for treatment services. Many youth workers have already identified a desperate need to establish more youth oriented treatment options, particularly for heroin users.

The study I referred to earlier also revealed a huge drop in the price of heroin. Heroin is now selling for around $280 a gram compared with $400 a gram only a year ago. Evidently Senator Vanstone's few well-publicised heroin hauls in recent months have had little impact on the increased supply of heroin entering the market. There is an urgent need to provide new treatment options and support services appropriate for catering to young people's specific needs.

The incidence of heroin use among young people is continuing to rise unabated. Understandably enough, treatment facilities dealing with patients whose serious addictions have spanned decades are often inappropriate environments for recovering teenage users. The need for more youth specific services also implies a need for more youth workers with experience in the drug and alcohol field. If youth specific strategies were to be implemented for the treatment of drug abuse in Australia, such workers would have a vital role to play in the provision of counselling and support services for participants. However, a large scale reallocation of resources towards youth specific services would be required in order to facilitate the development and implementation of new treatment options and support services for youth. While the current government's inaction and ineptitude on this issue continues, unfortunately, this is unlikely to happen.

Nevertheless, the enhancement of youth specific services should be considered a viable means of combating heroin abuse, in particular among young Australians. Kim Sattler from Canberra's own Woden Youth Centre has had years of experience in dealing with young people and is a strong advocate for providing more services for youth. `When we know that IV drug use is massively on the rise with under 25-year-olds, then if we don't want to lose a fair chunk of one generation then we better start looking at much more flexible options,' she has said. I am inclined to agree with her totally.

The crux of the matter is this: we need to start looking at the people and the problems separately. The people are not the problem. They merely have a problem. While we keep trying to punish them instead of helping them nothing will ever be achieved. The Prime Minister and his government talk about the war on drugs. The notion of war implies that we are on different sides. With any war there are casualties and victims. The government should not be on a different side to the people who use drugs; it should be on their side providing them with the help and support they need to address their problems.

The first casualty when war comes is truth. This government has sought to sidestep the issue of drug law reform with political posturing about being tough on drugs instead of initiating any honest new solutions. The Prime Minister rejected the recommendations of his own Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy last year when it concluded that the ACT heroin trial should go ahead. If the Prime Minister will not consider any new treatment options for heroin users, then I appeal to him to at least look at strengthening the current options with enhanced support services. We would not expect an alcoholic to be treated without proper counselling and support. Why do we expect heroin addicts to be able to go without such services when they are certainly fighting an addiction of similar magnitude?

The government must seek to remove the stigma that surrounds people who use heroin, rather than act to institutionalise it within the community. Equally, the growing problem of cocaine use will not be adequately addressed if the emphasis on heavy-handed law enforcement continues to dominate. It is time we started addressing the reason why Australia has a drug problem that is growing at an alarming rate. The time for punishment and persecution has surely passed. It is time to look at why decent, sensitive people in the community have to turn to drugs when they obviously feel there is no other option for them in their lives.

talk.start.para: —The first speech in a politician's career in either the House of Representatives or the Senate is a high point of that career as it is often a long and difficult road to achieve the honour of representing an electorate in this place or in the House of Representatives. When that end goal is achieved and the privileged few take their place, they do so with enormous pride, and first speeches generally reflect that pride. But, more importantly, first speeches often reflect community attitudes, aspirations and concerns in a very precise way. The reason is simple: first speeches are usually built around many hard months of campaigning, thousands of doors knocked upon and many public meetings attended. They also bring to the parliament a view not yet influenced by party pressures.

speech.para: For all of these reasons, the first speech of the member for Riverina, Mrs Kay Hull, makes very interesting reading. I assume that all of the National Party members in this place and all of her colleagues in the other place have had a chance to read it. Senator Boswell might want to have a few words to say about it here or somewhere else. Mrs Hull said that during the last campaign she travelled extensively, listening to the myriad of issues that people in her electorate, the electorate of Riverina, put to her. She said she had promised those people during the campaign that she would raise their concerns in the parliament if she were given the opportunity to do so. She told the House of Representatives that her first speech reflected those very concerns.

The new member for Riverina said the most pressing concern in country areas was the state of health services. She said that most of her constituents considered the health system to be in crisis. She said the lack of doctors, specialist services and trained nurses in rural areas was at crisis level. Mrs Hull need look no further than her own party and its coalition partner for the source of the problem. In just three years the Howard government has caused massive damage to health care, particularly in regional Australia. Bulk-billing rates have been forced down because the Howard government froze GP rebates. Public hospital funding has been slashed by many hundreds of millions of dollars. Mr Howard launched an assault on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. He closed Medicare offices, many of them in rural and regional Australia.

The Howard government also abolished the Commonwealth Dental Health Program, which Labor established in 1994 because Australians on low incomes had poor dental health and could not afford private dental care. That scheme offered free dental care to around four million pensioners and adult cardholders. During its lifetime it dramatically reduced waiting time for basic and emergency dental care and it greatly improved access to dental services in regional and rural Australia. Since this program's abolition, waiting lists have more than doubled and in some areas patients have to wait for years for essential dental treatment.

Mrs Hull also said in the other place that of equal concern to the people in Riverina was unemployment and the lack of job opportunities in rural and regional areas. Again, the cause of the problem lies with her own colleagues. The Howard government had not simply failed to give job creation in the bush the attention it justly deserves—that in itself would be bad enough; it actually abolished the Commonwealth Employment Service, which provided access to many job opportunities in regional Australia. Not only has this cost thousands of jobs directly with the closure of the CES offices around the nation, there have been many more indirect unemployment consequences, reinforcing the population shift from country to city. The replacement service, the Job Network, has been a spectacular failure, particularly in regional centres.
Mrs Hull also referred to economic rationalism. She said:

We are told, `Sell assets, shed debt, outsource and above all downsize, and the private sector jobs will come and economic growth will follow.' Unfortunately, with that process having been put into place, we are now faced with far more challenges to overcome. Our banks have gone, or are going. Our schools are closing. Our education, rail, taxation, electricity and other government departments have disappeared from our regional towns.

There is a difference between sound policy designed to develop efficient service delivery and efficient allocation of public resources as against ideological obsession. The former Labor government pursued good public policy in this regard. It implemented programs designed to achieve a range of objectives, which included universal service delivery with efficient service delivery. In contrast, this government has underpinned its approach to service delivery with an obsession for small government. In its view, small government is good and big government is bad.

In the 1996 election, the coalition described regional communities as `Australia's forgotten people'. After the election Mr Howard did not forget them, but perhaps it would have been better if he had. Mr Sharp, the former Minister for Transport and Regional Development, said:
There is not clear rationale or constitutional basis for Commonwealth involvement in regional development.

Then in its first budget, the government took to regional Australia with a vengeance. It cut funding for regional development assistance. It cut ABC services to rural and regional Australia. Now it wants to sell off the whole of Telstra, putting at risk communications in rural and regional Australia. It has cut funding for job programs in rural and regional Australia, and regional universities have been hit hard.

Mrs Hull also told the House of Representatives that aged care is in crisis. Every candidate who contested the last election would be of the same view. Aged care was undoubtedly one of the major failing policy areas of the first Howard government. There were endless changes to a fundamentally flawed policy, adversely affecting the most vulnerable in the community. Mrs Hull said:

. . . demand for dementia care far outstripping the supply of service that is available. Case loads on clinical nurses have doubled, but our operational days have been cut back. Increased demand for aged care hostels in rural areas cannot be satisfied.
Frankly, all of these problems can be laid at the feet of the Howard government.

Another area of community concern that Mrs Hull found during her campaign was the lack of adequate child-care services. She said child care was another area that has suffered in a world of rationalism, with far too few places and far too many families waiting to access quality child care for their precious children. She said this issue was contributing to a breakdown of the family unit. She was right on the mark and so were her constituents. Child care enables families to work and that means improved living standards and better opportunities for kids. Child-care centres are also important places of learning for young children.

Again, Mrs Hull need look no further than the Prime Minister for the source of the problem. In its first budget, the Howard government pushed up child-care costs and cut funding in this key area. On top of that, having cut $820 million in its first two budgets, it underspent its funding in its last budget.

The Howard government's assault on families, particularly families living in rural and regional Australia, has been comprehensive. There have been job cuts, cuts to funding for education, cuts to health, cuts to aged care assistance and cuts to the public hospitals. The new member for Riverina is in for a very tough time if she thinks that she can deliver solutions to the problems she discovered while campaigning—because, despite the rhetoric from the National Party, this is very much a government for the big end of town.

There is one other matter that I wish to raise today. All senators would be aware that both major parties went to the last election with a special package of measures for the state of Tasmania. The Labor package was designed to deal with the not insignificant economic difficulties facing the state. We had a plan, developed in consultation with the Tasmanian community. That package reflected the confidence Labor has in the future of Tasmania, given the right set of policies and the commitment to implement them.

However, the same cannot be said for the Howard government. While the government also presented a package of measures to Tasmanian voters at the last election, it was not committed to the future of the state. The Howard government's real view of Tasmania was stated by no less than the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, last Friday night. Mr Fischer was addressing the parliamentary press gallery annual dinner at the National Press Club. This is what he said about Tasmania: `the Tasmanian economy is a basket case.' He then said that the Tasmanian economy was `beyond repair'. It is important that everyone in Tasmania realise the significance of this statement for the future of the state under a Howard government. It means that the Howard government has given up on Tasmania and that this view will influence every cabinet decision.

Many of the problems currently facing the state are the result of misguided policies implemented by the government. Unfortunately, it now appears that the government has abandoned the state altogether. Perhaps the Tasmanian electorate abandoned the Liberal Party this year at both the state and federal levels in Tasmania, but there are two things that are certain: Labor will not abandon Tasmania and, frankly, Mr Fischer will be forced to eat his words.

talk.start.para: —Before I move the suspension of the Senate, I would like to make a few remarks about the treatment of regional Australia by the previous Labor government. We have heard from Senator O'Brien a range of comments about regional Australia. He needs to be reminded regularly, as do all honourable senators and particularly the people of Australia, of what happened under the previous government.

speech.para: This government is yet to have its third birthday. Most Australians, particularly those living in regional and remote Australia, would still not have forgotten what the Keating government did to them and what Mr Keating did as Treasurer—the sort of policies they pursued and the impact they had, particularly on people who lived in regional and remote areas. We saw under the 13 years of Labor government some of the greatest destruction of regional Australia in the history of this great nation.

That sort of economic devastation to industries in rural areas, to farms and stations throughout this country, had not been witnessed since the 1930s Depression. The sort of devastation that occurred to individual households had only occurred at one other time in Australia's history since our foundation, indeed since Federation, and that was during the Great Depression. It took—to use a phrase that my father coined—`extremely sexy fingers' on the part of then Treasurer Mr Keating and Prime Minister Hawke, and in the latter period of that government Prime Minister Keating, to wreak the havoc that they wreaked on regional and rural Australia. Senator O'Brien may well get up and wish to say that he did not support that previous government and that he has found a new way forward—the Blair way, the Beazley way, the Conroy way, the Carr way, or whatever the new way forward is for the Labor Party; because I know they are grasping around in the darkness trying to find a solution, let alone a policy—

talk.start.para: —The Mark Latham method.

—I guess they have got a few options available to them. He may say that he is part of the new face of Labor. We will never let the people of Australia forget, if their memories get hazy, what happened particularly to regional and rural Australia. Senator O'Brien comes in here, as have other Labor senators in the past few years, and discusses regional and rural issues and what is happening in regional and rural Australia. They are right to do that, but they must remember the legacy of the 13 years of the Hawke and Keating governments.

speech.para: Madam Acting Deputy President, you understand that, coming as you do from Western Australia. You saw what happened to the outback areas, the pastoral and mining districts, of Western Australia—those great provinces. You saw what happened in the agricultural districts of our great state—the destruction of towns, the destruction of families and the destruction of family farming enterprises—when the economic vandals on the other side of the aisle were in government. They increased the interest rates that farmers had to pay. In fact, any entrepreneurial enterprise or business had to pay rates above 30 per cent in some respects. People who had farming equipment and other infrastructure financed through finance companies in this nation were forced, during the Keating treasurership and prime ministership, to pay rates of over 30 per cent on their business loans. They were wiped out.

This was from a government and from a Treasurer who, at the time, said that he had his hands on the levers. My father's phrase about sexy fingers—for those who cannot pick it up—is for people who have their hands on these levers, but when they touch things with these fingers they stuff them. That is what these people did to the economy of Australia. Not content to wipe out regional and rural Australian businesses, farms and stations and the mining industry with their $10 billion annual deficit—year after year, for 10 out of the 13 years these people chose to spend $10 billion more than they earned—or to mortgage the future of young Australians, who will have to pay this debt back, they wreaked this economic destruction.

But they were not content with that. When it came to confronting the unusual constitutional problem caused by the High Court's decision in the Mabo 2 case, they had the opportunity to work constructively with the states, who have constitutional responsibility for land management, but they threw that away. They walked away from negotiations with the states and said, `We will go it alone. We want to appeal to the cappuccino set, the chardonnay set, in the suburbs of Melbourne and Sydney.'

They did not want to do the hard yards trying to find a solution to the problems caused by the constitutional issues relating to Mabo 2. They walked away. They ran it alone and imposed on this nation what became known as the Mabo legislation which, technically, is the Native Title Act 1993.

talk.start.para: —Totally unworkable.

—It delivered a land management system in Australia that was totally unworkable, to use Senator Coonan's words. It effectively closed down exploration in this country and sent it offshore. It put geologists and lots of blue collar workers out of work across this country. It particularly harshly impacted on regional and remote areas of Australia. It was a double whammy from these people opposite. When you come into this place, Madam Acting Deputy President, I ask you and I ask members opposite to think very carefully about the credibility that they bring to a debate about regional and rural Australia after the havoc that they have wreaked across this country.

speech.para: It will take, I hope, generations to forgive those opposite for what they did to this nation in the last 13 years. I hope it takes generations but, more sincerely, I hope that members opposite will sit down and do the hard yards in relation to policy that will be constructive for Australia. They have just spent 2½ years sniping and carping, and being obstructive and negative and saying no to everything and overturning any principles that Labor may have ever had. If they want to be a serious opposition that can propose serious alternative policies they firstly have to find themselves a direction.

As I said earlier, there are five or six different proposals from various people, but none from the leader, of course. He is totally devoid of any ideas. He has run out of ideas and run out of oomph, and he certainly never had any ticker. But there is a range of other proposals. Mark Latham is putting forward some proposals, and I see Senator Conroy is talking about finding a fourth or fifth way. There are other people talking about a third way. You can copy the Clinton model or the Blair model. They could look at the Mitterrand model. Those people are looking for a way forward for Labor.

Let us hope they find a way because, in a Westminster democracy, you need a serious opposition. We do not have one at the moment. We have a rabble of opportunists with a record of economic destruction in this nation that is second to none. No other governments were so bad for Australia as were the Hawke and Keating governments. Let us hope they find a way but let us never forget what they did to this country. Let us never forget what they did to regional and rural Australia. Whenever Labor senators get up and have a go at this government, just remind them what they did.

This government has delivered five per cent economic growth at a time when the region is in economic recession. These guys had trouble delivering any growth at all when the region was growing at eight, 10 and 12 per cent. We have cut interest rates to levels that have not been seen since the 1930s so that farmers, home buyers and home owners can benefit to the tune of about $300, or more, a month for a $100,000 mortgage. We are putting money in the pockets of these people.

The people in regional and remote Australia have got more money in their pockets now as a result of this government's sound economic management. We are getting rid of those $10 billion deficits and turning them into surpluses for the first time in generations. Yet these people come in and want to play games. The hypocrisy is breathtaking but let us never stop reminding them of what they did. I certainly never will. As long as I am allowed the honour of serving in this place, I will take any opportunity to do that.

talk.start.para: —I might use this brief occasion before question time to respond to some of Senator Campbell's comments. Senator Campbell chose to ride on the back of Senator O'Brien's contribution, so he deserves some response. He refers to the comments of Labor senators on several of the macro-economic issues that face us today and the impact on regional economies. It has amused me somewhat because I was taking the opportunity to acquaint myself with the work done by what was the old DEETYA committee on regional unemployment during my period of duty today and some of his comments do not quite fit with much of the evidence that was received by that committee. However, we will have an opportunity, probably early next year, to put down a report of that committee's consideration in relation to regional unemployment. We can perhaps better address some of those issues then.

speech.para: Senator Campbell referred to the views of Labor senators in relation to regions, but Senator O'Brien was highlighting the contribution made by the new member for Riverina in his speech. I was somewhat amused to see this front-on attack from Senator Campbell, this sniping at Labor senators and the reminders about 13 years of government. There are a couple of points that he failed to address in his brief contribution to today's considerations.

Firstly, the reason that we are grappling, in a policy sense, for what he chooses to call the second, third, fourth or fifth way is that we need to deal with the impact of globalisation on regions in Australia. Since Senator Campbell chose not to proffer any proposed solutions for these regions, he is in some difficulty—with respect to the vast amount of evidence that has been put to the Senate committee on the problems still being faced by regions—in suggesting that his government has offered any succour to those people that have been suffering disadvantage for many years.

It is easy for us to stand up here and highlight one section or one industry and ignore any other industries, but I think the interjection made by Senator O'Brien was quite valid: `What about today's wheat industry?' Until we all acknowledge that there are significant problems in this area and do not resort to brief quips about `sexy fingers' and all those sorts of comments, and until we address these problems seriously we are a long way from finding any way for Australia to generate economies and employment for our youth of the future and to survive in a globalised economy.

I also do not think it is reasonable in relation to growth statistics to create figures, as Senator Campbell did to suit his argument. Yes, there has been most recently a five per cent growth figure under the current government, and I will be very happy if that level of growth is sustained and if it is generated and distributed into growth in employment and sustainable economies in regional Australia. But I do not think the government has the record over a lengthy period of time in relation to sustained growth to be able to proffer the sort of complacency that Senator Campbell did in his earlier contribution. If anything, the consistent and sustainable economic growth under the period of Labor government stands up much better than does Senator Campbell's brief five per cent figure.

Senator Campbell also surprised me with his reference to the need for a serious opposition. I would have thought that, after the last election results, he would have realised how very close his own government came to being in opposition after just one term. Talking about serious oppositions, perhaps the Labor Party is in a position to say, `In some senses, we were lucky—through the current government's mismanagement—to be in the position to offer the sort of opposition we were able to after such a sort period.' As Senator Campbell highlighted, this government has not even reached its third birthday. It was at about its second and a half birthday before we faced the last election. It had not even reached its third birthday when it was nearly out on its ear.

Senator Campbell would want to be careful about his reference to serious oppositions, because we are still waiting to see serious government. Contributions such as his own, following Senator O'Brien's highlighting of criticism from within Senator Campbell's own ranks, reflect poorly on the ability of this government and its representatives currently in the chamber to offer a serious debate.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 1.48 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Minister, I refer you to recent reports that the National Australia Bank is about to enter the final phase of its campaign to convince the Prime Minister and the Treasurer to allow it to merge with another major bank. Is it the case that, despite having explicitly ruled out any relaxation of the four pillars policy, the Prime Minister has agreed to meet with Mr Argus of the NAB to discuss the issue? Given that the NAB saved the Liberal Party from bankruptcy in the mid-1990s, will the minister confirm that there will be, as the Prime Minister has stated, no relaxation of the four pillars policy?
—I actually thought that Senator Conroy was going to ask me about branch stacking in the Labor Party in Victoria and the Dreyfus report, so I pulled out that brief. I will put it away.
—Pull the Bulleen one out.
—Of course you would be extremely sensitive about it, Senator Conroy, after the particular attack that you were under in the Labor Party in Victoria.
—Senator Kemp, I remind you of the question that was asked of you by Senator Conroy.
—Thank you, Madam President.

answer.para: Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It is very difficult to pursue this important question with Senator Ray calling out all the time and then trying to defend Senator Conroy. Why would you try to defend Senator Conroy, who is, in my view, indefensible? The government's position on the four pillars policy is absolutely clear. On the ABC's AM program on 30 November, the Treasurer said:

answer.para: So in the situation as we find it now . . . you can't conceive that allowing mergers would improve competition.
The Prime Minister said in his address to the National Farmers Federation on 24 November:

Our position on bank mergers is this: that we are not for all time against mergers of existing banks. But we would not agree to any mergers taking place, any further mergers of the majors, in other words we'd maintain what's called the four pillars policy, until we are satisfied that there was a greater level of competition than now exists.

So the government's position on the four pillars policy is absolutely clear. The four pillars policy is in place and will remain in place until such a time as there is a greater level of competition than now exists. I do not know what Senator Conroy is on about. I think it is important that the Prime Minister and ministers have a wide range of meetings with community and business groups and business and community leaders. I think that is perfectly appropriate. If I were you, Senator Conroy, I would not worry too much about the four pillars policy.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware of Mr Argus's advice to the Prime Minister that banks cannot lend to small business at the same rates as they do for home mortgages because it is more risky? Given that banks demand a mortgage on both the small business and usually the home of the small business operator, does the minister agree with the NAB that lending to small business is more risky under these circumstances? What effect does this attitude from the NAB to small business have on the relaxation of the four pillars?
—I suspect I may even get a question on the level of interest rates today, so I invite you to tune in to my response. Mr Argus is entitled to put views and is entitled to argue his case.
—What is your response?

—My response is that Mr Argus is entitled to put views to the government if he wishes to and is entitled to argue his case. My response—and I refer you to the first part of my answer—is that the four pillars policy is in place, and I quoted for you comments from the Treasurer and the Prime Minister on this particular issue.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. There have been six cuts in official interest rates since the Howard government came to office. This means an after tax saving of some $3,000 in interest payments for Australians with an average sized mortgage. Will the minister explain what the benefits are for families and small businesses?

—I thank Senator Calvert—the very popular and efficient whip on the government side—and welcome that question from him. Since the Reserve Bank capped official interest rates at 4.75 per cent, financial institutions, including all the major banks, have announced cuts in their home mortgage rates and in some cases their lending rates to business. These rate cuts are a terrific Christmas present for Australian families and business.

answer.para: Madam President, you may recall that, when this government came into office, the standard variable mortgage rate was some 10.5 per cent. This rate is now 6.5 per cent. Just to reiterate that: when Senator Conroy's government was in office, the standard variable home mortgage rate was 10.5 per cent. It is now 6.5 per cent, with some home loan rates going below six per cent. I think we can all recall on this side—as, indeed, Australian families and people in business can recall—the very high level of interest rates which occurred under the previous government. The Labor Party was a high interest rate government, and this government is a low interest rate government.

Under the former Keating government, interest rates reached a staggering 17 per cent—a 17 per cent slug on home loans. This is what the Labor Party delivered to Australian families. It is no wonder that, every time elections come around, the Australian community and Australian families remember—

talk.start.para: —The National Bank bailed you out.

—They remember, Senator Conroy, the very high interest rates which occurred under the former government. Since the government has been elected, as a result of the interest rate cuts an Australian family with an average mortgage is saving probably more than $3,000 per annum in interest—an enormous saving in interest. As a result of our policies, a terrific Christmas present has been able to be delivered to Australian families. These cuts in interest rates have been a result of the very sound policies which have been followed by the Howard government.

answer.para: Virtually all our major policies, all the major initiatives in the economy and elsewhere, have been opposed by the Labor Party, but we have delivered growth of five per cent in the 12 months to September, the lowest home mortgage rates since the 1960s, 400,000 new jobs since March 1996 and the highest number of ANZ job vacancies since March 1990. Inflation rates are at or near the 25-year lows. It is a remarkable achievement and it is no wonder that the Australian community, faced with a choice of returning Labor to office or sticking with a government that can carry out sensible and positive reforms and deliver real benefits, real jobs and real growth in the economy to Australian families, chose the Howard government. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Small Business

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. I refer the minister to comments by the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, who stated:

question.para: Some small businesses will need to think carefully about their accounting systems, for example . . . and perhaps look at the computers that they have got now to make sure that they are up to date.

How many of Australia's one million small businesses will need to upgrade their computing systems as a consequence of the GST? Is it a fact that small businesses required to change their accounting and computer systems to accommodate the GST will on average receive only $500 worth of government assistance? Is the minister aware that the Institute of Chartered Accountants has today described this figure as `unrealistic'? What does the government estimate the cost will be to small businesses required to overhaul their accounting and computing systems for the GST?

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Sherry for his question. This tax reform policy is delivering huge benefits to Australian families and huge benefits to Australian business. My colleague Senator Minchin in an answer earlier this week mentioned the enormous costs which are coming off small business as a result of the tax reforms this government is bringing in.

answer.para: Senator, I am not sure whether you are aware that in relation to the very important changes in many of the accounting arrangements and the withholding tax arrangements the Labor Party adopted our policy. You will remember that when you brought out your failed tax reform policy, at the back of it you tacked on all the changes that this government had proposed in relation to PAYE and the changes in all the withholding tax arrangements. You adopted holus-bolus virtually all the proposed changes which we brought in, without the GST, and which would have led to huge costs to small business.

The government has in its policy clearly recognised that there will be some costs. That is why we have provided a very substantial sum, $500 million, to assist in this process. There is a consultative committee which is now looking at the best and most effective way to distribute this assistance. I think that certainly makes sense.

The government, as always, will work closely with small business. Unlike the Labor Party, we do not attack small business. We are anxious to deliver to small business, as we have been able to do since we came to office, major cuts in interest rates. We have been anxious to deliver cuts in red tape, which we have delivered. We are bringing in tax reforms which are to the benefit of small business. We just do not accept the nitpicking arrangements and complaints that we constantly get from the Labor Party on tax reform.

Small business remember that the Labor Party brought in the unfair dismissals law. Small business remember the changes and the introduction of the FBT which the Labor Party brought in. Small business, Senator Sherry, have very long memories about the Labor Party. Small business remember how you favoured trade union interests over business interests. Senator, you would be pleased to know that small business strongly supported tax reform at the election. This government is going to deliver on that promise and calls on the Senate to make sure that the government promises can be delivered in full and on time.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question. I am glad, Minister, that you admit that there will be `some costs', to use your words, but this is significantly more than nitpicking. Certainly small business have made representations to us about the costs. Are you aware that small businesses requiring outside assistance to update their computing systems will face a shortage of skilled IT personnel as a consequence of pressures caused by the millennium bug? What will be the additional cost to small business of hiring IT personnel as a consequence of this short age? What assistance, if any, does the government intend to provide to overcome this problem?

—You will be aware that in the last budget some changes were brought in. The government has announced some changes in relation to the millennium bug. I think those changes will provide assistance to business. Senator Sherry's concern for small business, as I have said, is entirely misplaced. Tax reform is about helping small business.
—A lot of them don't believe it.

—They do believe it, Senator. Even more importantly, when the choice came at the last election they voted for us; they did not vote for you. We believe that tax reform will provide a huge benefit to small business. Small business appreciate what this government has done and what it is trying to do in the way of tax reform. We have received extremely strong support from small business. The only people who complain are the Labor Party. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Health: Services in Regional and Remote Australia

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Ian Macdonald. Will the minister outline the government achievements and initiatives in improving the delivery of health services in regional and remote Australia?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —That is a very important question from Senator Knowles. I thank her for her question. I know that Senator Knowles and her Western Australian colleagues have a big interest in rural and regional Australia and the initiatives that the government is promoting for those of us who live in rural and regional Australia.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There is far too much yelling in the chamber from those on my left. I would ask them to cease.

—Senator Knowles will be pleased to hear that the coalition government is focused on delivering high quality health care to regional and remote Australians. We recognise that we need more doctors in rural and regional areas and that we need to encourage doctors that are currently there to stay. In the past, rural and regional communities have had difficulties in attracting and retaining doctors. We work with rural communities, with professional bodies and with educational institutions to overcome these obstacles.

answer.para: We have put in place a number of initiatives that will be very useful to people living in rural and regional Australia. One of Senator Knowles's colleagues, Senator Eggleston, actually practised medicine in rural and regional Australia for many, many years in a very distinguished way. We are going to provide an additional $30 million for more doctors in remote and rural Australia. We have committed to funding $50 million more to a program of general practitioner retention payments for practitioners living in rural and remote areas. This is to stop the flow of doctors out of rural and regional areas in Australia. It is a very good move.

This is on top of the increase in funding that the government has made for public hospitals right across Australia of some 19.2 per cent over five years. Public hospitals in rural and regional Australia and everywhere else in Australia will benefit very significantly from the huge increase that the federal government will give in public hospital funding over the next five years. We are also providing $31.3 billion in funding for public hospitals over the next five years. I want to repeat that, because it is an enormous investment by this government in public hospitals over the next five years—$31.3 billion. That is more than any other government in Australian history has ever provided for hospitals.

Senator Knowles will also be interested to know that we are providing $41.6 million for 30 new rural multipurpose health and family service centres. These centres are targeted to sites in small rural communities with populations of around 2,000 people. At the present time, 35 multipurpose service centres are operating throughout Australia. The Labor Party might be interested—I know my side is—to know that there are 14 in New South Wales, six in Victoria, two in Queensland, four in South Australia, seven in Western Australia and one each in Tasmania and the Northern Territory.

These existing and new multipurpose service centres will provide a range of services which include health and medical services such as immunisation, palliative care and mental health, support services such as community nursing, home care and Meals on Wheels, child care, infant welfare and parenting information. We will be supporting supported accommodation services, such as nursing home and hostel care. As well, the Medicare Ezyclaim system was introduced into rural and remote areas as part of our government's commitment to making Medicare services more accessible. We are going to improve upon that. We have committed $30 million to install a further 600 Medicare Ezyclaim facilities. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, will the programs that you have just outlined—which the Labor Party have overlooked and carefully misrepresent—be supplemented by other government initiatives for regional areas?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Senator Knowles. Again, you ask a very worthwhile question, one that I am pleased to answer. I did not mention the fact that, over the past two years, this government has established university departments of rural health in each state and the Northern Territory, committing more than $27 million in funds. These departments provide rural health, education training and support for health care professionals with an emphasis on rural population health.

answer.para: Very importantly, I am very pleased to mention that the government will provide a $10 million capital injection to the James Cook University medical school in Townsville—my home town—for 20 new medical places and another $13.2 million to the University of New South Wales for a clinical school at Wagga Wagga. The importance of that is that we on this side believe that if you train doctors in rural and regional areas they will stay there. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Credit Unions

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Is the minister aware that Ross McDowell, the General Manager of the Queensland Credit Union, has described the Treasurer's response to concerns about the impact of the GST on credit unions as `patronising' and `smart alec'? Is the minister also aware of Mr McDowell's claim that the GST would remove a `significant competition influence on the banks', as the GST will apply to credit unions when the same services offered by the banks will be exempt? Is Mr McDowell correct? Is the government serious about competition in the financial sector when the impact of the GST on credit unions will clearly have the opposite effect?

—Unlike the Labor Party, this government has been very supportive of credit unions. We have been able to increase the ability of credit unions to compete, particularly through the payment of cheques, which has been widely welcomed by the credit unions. That was one of the initiatives which this government was able to carry out on behalf of credit unions. Senator, the Treasurer has answered some questions in the parliament on this. I do not know if the comments you quoted were quoted in full or accurately but, if they were, I think the comments that were made were unfortunate comments. The fact of the matter is that we are seeking to treat all financial institutions in a similar manner on a level playing field. I think that what we have carried out in that area will do that.

answer.para: We are aware that the credit unions have put particular views to the government. I am sure there will be other institutions in the financial sector which will also have views. But we are treating all those financial institutions in a similar fashion. I think that that is the appropriate way to do it. I know that the credit unions have requested that sales from the Credit Union Services Corporation to them should be GST free. We are aware of that particular proposal that they have put to us, but to accept that would be to treat credit unions in a special fashion compared with other financial institutions.

On the general point, we would expect all financial institutions to benefit from the sorts of reforms that this government is carrying out. One of those reforms is in the tax area. An important feature of those reforms will be to make the Australian economy more competitive to enable the Australian economy to grow at a higher rate to deliver real benefits to Australian consumers. The tax cuts will provide greater disposable income to taxpayers. That will be of benefit to financial institutions as well.

Tax reform is one of the important measures we went to the Australian people on. We outlined in detail at the election the proposals that the government intended to put into effect when we were elected. We were elected and we intend to carry out our major tax reform initiatives. I suggest that the Senate and the Labor Party accept that this government won the election on the basis of a number of policies, but particularly on the policy of tax reform.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, what is the government doing to effectively assist credit unions in remaining competitive against the big banks? You talk about a level playing field, but in actual fact the big banks get special treatment. Could you, in the light of your comments, please explain what the government's policy is to assist credit unions? Will you give an undertaking for you or the Treasurer to meet with the credit unions to listen to their very real concerns?

—Of course I am happy to meet with the credit unions. I have already had discussions with some of the representatives of credit unions. If they wish to meet further with me, all they have to do is phone my office. They do not have to get a Labor senator to ask me a question in the parliament. They would find that, if they gave my office a call directly, I would be more than happy to meet with them.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Senator Ian Macdonald. Minister, does the government stand by the joint media release issued by Ministers John Fahey and Mark Vaile on 20 March 1998 which promised in part that Canberra airport's new operator will be subject to, for the term of its operating lease, a comprehensive regulatory regime that will ensure that public interest is fully protected? Minister, why have there been savage increases of over 300 per cent in rents and flying charges to Canberra airport's small business operators when the government promised in its media release that aeronautical charges would be capped at CPI minus one for the next five years?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Senator Woodley mentions a media release. I must say that I am not familiar with it. I would assume it was released some months ago. I would also assume that the ministers involved would not have any reason to change their minds. What I understand about the Canberra airport is that it is going to mean a huge boost to the economy of this part of regional Australia and to the Capital Territory.

answer.para: Madam President, you would understand—and you would be very well aware of this from the marvellous representations you make for this area, if I might say so—the great importance Canberrans place on their airport and the fact that it is being upgraded, that it is now in private hands and that it will provide more and more air activity and more and more jobs over time to people in this part of regional Australia. Senator Woodley, I have read in the paper that there were some rentals going up. I am not sure that that applies to the regulatory charges that I think you said the particular media release related to. I suspect that you might be talking about apples where they were talking about oranges.

talk.start.para: —Pineapples.
—Or pineapples. If that is not correct, I will discuss the matter with Mr Anderson to see if he wants to comment further on the matter you have mentioned.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his commitment to discuss this with Minister Anderson. I also thank you for your answer to my question the other day about airports. Minister, are you aware that a protest meeting was held yesterday at the Canberra airport which passed a motion to demand the Howard federal government honour its promise to provide an effective price cap at phase 2 privatised airports to prevent this type of monopolistic exploitation of airport users? Minister, will the government honour the promises made in the Fahey-Vaile media release?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I cannot really add further to the answer I gave previously. I will refer that to Mr Anderson and see if he can get a comprehensive answer for Senator Woodley.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Self-funded Retirees

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Minister, I refer to the Prime Minister's repeated assurances that no-one will be worse off under the GST. Can the minister confirm that a self-funded retiree who receives between $30,000 and $40,000 per annum will not be eligible for either the aged persons savings bonus or the self-funded retirees supplementary bonus, worth $3,000 dollars? Minister, is such a self-funded retiree, who has no assets other than their private pension income, considered well off by the government? If not, will the government be extending the pension bonus scheme to this group of self-funded retirees to adequately compensate them for the imposition of the GST and so ensure that they are not worse off?

—Thank you, Senator Faulkner, for that question on the government's very important initiative of tax reform. Senator, the tax reform proposal has been out since August, and I must say that the Labor Party has failed to produce examples of people who will be worse off. That challenge was thrown out during the election when, in fact, community attention was focused on this, and the Labor Party failed to produce examples of people who would be worse off as a result of the tax reform package. Senator Faulkner mentioned the supplementary savings bonus. Amongst other things, this bonus is available to people who have personal income from savings and investments, either in—

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I directed a question to Senator Kemp about a self-funded retiree who received between $30,000 and $40,000 per annum, and asked, effectively—in, I thought, a very good question—whether such a person would be worse off under the GST. So I think it is a very clear question, a specific example, and I would ask you, given Senator Kemp's opening remarks, to ask him to address those very serious concerns in his answer.
—Senator Kemp, I just remind you of the question. You should remain relevant to the issue.

—Madam President, you do not have to remind me of the question because, as I was saying, the supplementary bonus is available to people who had, among other things, less than $30,000 in total income in 1998-99 or 1999-2000. But, Senator Faulkner, I think you forgot to mention that this person may well benefit from income tax cuts, which we are delivering in spades. You forgot to mention that this person may well benefit from the refundable franking credit changes which we brought in. You failed to mention, of course, that this person may well benefit from the health insurance rebate, which the Labor Party is attempting to deny many people in this particular category.

answer.para: So for you, Senator Faulkner, to get up and complain is quite extraordinary, because you and your party are attempting to prevent the tax reform package going through. You are attempting to prevent the major tax cuts that we want to deliver to Australian families going through. It is our party that announced the franking credits initiative which will be of enormous benefit to self-funded retirees, and it is our party that is attempting to deliver a major benefit through the health insurance rebate, which self-funded retirees, above all, are demanding. They are demanding this assistance with private health insurance. It is the Labor Party which is attempting to prevent—

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. I think the minister has had adequate opportunity to explain to the Senate whether a self-funded retiree earning between $30,000 and $40,000 per annum will be worse off under the GST.
