We are very concerned that the data from the department seems often to be lagging behind the evidence put forward in submissions to the committee. In particular, there is some doubt about the number of child-care centres that have closed. In my own state a number of centres have closed, more of which are community based centres rather than private centres. Yet nowhere is there coherent data from the department that lists those centres that have closed. Indeed, there is some argument by the department that the evidence people provide for us is not factual.

In passing, I have to say that a lot of the comment in this report refers to `anecdotal' evidence. I think we need to be careful of the use of this adjective because it is in some ways pejorative. If anybody from a state writes to say that a certain number of centres have closed, and this is not substantiated by departmental data, that it might be described as anecdotal evidence does carry with it the sense that it is just a claim and not hard evidence. Many of the people who have gone to the bother of putting in submissions are people who are working in the industry, people from peak organisations who are very aware of the state of play of their member participants. So I do think we have to be cautious about the use of the word `anecdotal', particularly as it sometimes conveys a considerable pejorative tone.

I think it is important that we do have evidence from the department that is completely up-to-date. The department, for example, has to know how many people are using child care in how many centres so that it can properly provide—I suppose it is now through Centrelink—the approval of child-care assistance to the eligible recipients in those centres. I find it a bit confusing that we might be claiming to have accurate data for the payment of child-care assistance but less than clear data and numbers about those child-care centres that have closed and those that are open. Others might wish to make different comment about that, but I certainly think it is very important.

The clear evidence before this committee was that the costs of child care have risen, that child care is less affordable, and that this is impacting hardest on people on the lowest incomes. The committee is also concerned about what is meant by `affordable' and has urged the department in recommendations to try to produce some harder data on what could be meant by affordability of child care. If we are going to say that child care has become less affordable, it is clear that the price rises and the cost increases have had an impact. That means that the price rises and the cost increases are definite and real.
In the few minutes remaining to me I wish to refer to outside school hours care. Paragraph 4.125 at page 75 of the report states:
Witnesses also pointed to closure of services as evidence of the adverse impact of loss of the operational subsidy.
Here we do have hard evidence from the department, which the report notes was given by the Department of Health and Family Services in answer to Senate question on notice No. 202:
Between July 1997 and July 1998, 98 OSHC services (before school care/ after school care/ vacation care) had closed.
This section of the report starts with a very interesting quote from the National Out of School Hours Services Association, which I would like to read into the record:

OSHC services did not grow out of government initiatives like other child care services, rather it `sprang from within the community as part of a growing need for safe play opportunities lost to children as society changed in the 1970s and the neighbourhood of backyards, streets, footpaths and mothers in starched white aprons disappeared.

I am not sure about the mothers in starched white aprons. But what we do know is that there was a major concern some few years back—I would say the late 1970s, early 1980s—about children usefully defined as latchkey kids—children who would be left at home as both parents or a single parent were working. These parents were not able to be at home for the children and those children became described, I think very succinctly, as latchkey kids.

What is emerging from the evidence in this report is that, with the closure of 98 outside school hours care services, we are seeing latchkey kids emerge again. If we are concerned about our parents working with less stress and less anxiety and therefore being more productive, and particularly if we are concerned about the safety and the protection of our children, it is essential that we do not revert to the latchkey practices that led to the community initiatives in this area.

The operational subsidy cutbacks in this area have proved disastrous. There has been too much of an administrative burden on the centres and therefore many of them have been forced to close. There has been an increase in child-care assistance in the area but the administrative costs of replacing the operational subsidy with the increased child-care assistance has created a burden that has led directly to the closure of many of those centres.

This Senate should have a major concern about the emergence of a new generation of latchkey kids. We know the evidence. We know how disastrous that was. We know how important it was to see the outside school hours care services emerge. It is a terrible pity that government policies might lead to a dramatic and long-term existence of another generation of such children.

I have here a very full child-care funding inquiry tabling statement which shortly I will ask to be incorporated. In the last minute left to me and just in closing, I would say that it concerns me that, when I first came into this parliament in 1996, I chaired in this place a report on early childhood, called Childhood matters: Report on the inquiry into early childhood education. That is a three-year-old report and, to my knowledge, there has never been a government response to the very important recommendations throughout that report about child care, early childhood education and sufficient support for children. I sincerely hope that the government can, in addressing the report now before us, take the time to look at the recommendations of that earlier report and provide it to the Senate. As I foreshadowed, I seek leave to have that tabling statement and its many more full comments about this whole area incorporated.
Leave granted.
The tabling statement read as follows—

The child care industry in Australia has grown significantly over the last decade. The Department of Family and Community Services indicated that at December 1997 some 432,700 children used Commonwealth-funded long day care services including family day care. The Commonwealth provides funding to families through Childcare Assistance and the Childcare Rebate and to child care services through capital grants and operational subsidies. Commonwealth expenditure on child care was $1.06 billion in 1994-95 and is projected to reach $1.21 billion in 2000-2001.

The Committee's inquiry into child care funding arose as a result of widespread concern about the impact of the changes to the Commonwealth's funding of child care announced in both the 1996-97 and 1997-98 budgets. Among these changes were:
. the abolition of the operational subsidy for community-based long day child care centres;
. limiting Childcare Assistance to 50 hour per week;
. limiting non-work related Childcare Assistance to 20 hours per week;
. freezing of the indexation of the Childcare Assistance Fee Ceiling and the Childcare Rebate Ceiling for two years;
. the introduction of a new income-tested Childcare Assistance payment for school age children using Commonwealth-approved child care centres for before school, after school and vacation care; and
. the introduction of a National Planning System for new child care places.

The Committee's inquiry attracted widespread interest throughout Australia and it undertook an extensive program of public hearings. To allow as many individuals as possible to put their views, the Committee held community forums at five of its eight hearings. The Committee also provided an opportunity for representatives of care providers including both community based and private long day care centres, family day care services, out of school hours services and vacation care services to give evidence. The Department of Family and Community Services ('the Department'), peak groups, State and local government and unions also gave evidence.

In undertaking its inquiry, the Committee received a great deal of anecdotal evidence about the impacts of the changes to child care funding on services and families. At the same time, there were difficulties in gaining up-to-date statistical information which accurately reflected the state of the industry following the changes. In particular, the Department acknowledged limitations to its data on recent closures of centres. The Department is working towards improving its data collection and analysis. However, the Committee has recommended that the Department, in conjunction with other major collectors of data on children's services, adopt a more coordinated approach to data collection to ensure that overlap and deficiencies in the current data collection are overcome.

Community-based services provided evidence about the impacts of the abolition of the operational subsidy. It was stated that fees had increased as a result of the loss of the subsidy. Increases ranged from relatively small amounts to as much as $30 per week. Other means of compensating for the loss of the subsidy included reduction in the levels of staffing, loss of support staff such as cleaners and cooks, reduction of services including the provision of cooked meals and nappy services and closure of baby places.

The Committee did not support the reintroduction of the operational subsidy for community-based long day care centres. However, the Committee considers that both the community-based and private services have a valuable role to play in the provision of child care in Australia. They provide alternative models for the management of child care services and provide families with choice of care and choice in level of participation in the provision of services for their children. The community-based sector also makes an important contribution to the social capital and infrastructure of communities. Further, the Committee considers that the growth of one type of service provider to the detriment of the other would not be a positive outcome for the industry.

The Committee has recommended that the Commonwealth provide support for the industry by encouraging both service types and in particular ensuring that community-based services continue as viable service providers. The Committee also recommended that in order to ensure the continuing viability of community-based services a one-off grant be provided to them in recognition of the additional costs associated with supporting management committees and the need to upgrade management facilities to improve efficiency. Further, consideration should be given to expanding funding for restructuring within the community-based sector and to providing funding for the development of innovative models of child care based on the community development approach.

In regard to the limiting of Childcare Assistance to 50 hour limit per week, the Committee considered that it was appropriate that a limit be placed on access to assistance that goes to unused care. Provisions are available for an exemption to the limit for those families who are genuinely in need of more care. However, the Committee does consider that the evidence received highlighted a significant area of competing goals wherein the Commonwealth is trying to restrict the number of hours of unused care for which Childcare Assistance is claimed and service providers are attempting to meet demands for care which require them to open centres for more than 50 hours per week. The Committee has recommended that the review of centres' charging practices which has been referred to the Child Care Advisory Council be conducted as a matter of priority.

The Committee considers that the 20 hour limit on non-work related care is adequate. Provisions are in place to exempt from the limit families in crisis situations and families with a child who has a disability.

para.inline: Impacts of the changes on long day care centres

speech.para: Evidence was received that the major impact of the changes on the child care industry has been to the viability of the industry. It was stated that fees had increased as a direct result of the funding changes and that this had occurred at a time when the amount of assistance offered to families had decreased. Fee increases have had an adverse impact on utilisation rates. Many providers stated that cost cutting, particularly in the area of staffing, was affecting the quality and variety of services offered. Witnesses stated that centres had closed as a direct result of the funding changes and that further closures were anticipated.

The Committee considers that the child care industry is going through a period of great change and that there are a number of variables interacting in a complex way within the industry. Some are the result of the Commonwealth's changes to funding. However, the child care industry is also influenced by changes to State regulations under which services operate and which have resulted in cost increases in the past. Centres also experience changes in costs associated with employing staff and running a business.

The Committee concludes that oversupply of places is a significant factor influencing the industry at the moment. The National Planning System will assist decision making in the future to ensure the growth of a viable child care industry. However, in the interim there will be continued rationalisation in the industry.

With regard to quality of care, the Committee heard evidence that the changes to child care funding have impacted adversely on the quality of care being offered. The Committee does not consider that there is a major difference in the quality of care offered by either type of service and has noted that the proportion of community-based centres and private centres meeting accreditation standards is very similar.

Access to Childcare Assistance for OSHC services was supported by many witnesses. However, many expressed the view that the operational subsidies for OHSC services were still required to provided a secure funding base as, unlike long day care centres, they do not have predictable utilisation rates. It was noted that the new system imposed a greater administrative burden on OSHC services and families.

The Committee is concerned that so many OSHC services have closed since December 1997 and that some witnesses predicted further closures before the end of 1998. The Committee considers that OSHC services are disadvantaged by the introduction of the Childcare Assistance only model of funding.

Witnesses also stated that fees had increased in OSHC services as a result of the changes. As a result there had been a growth in the number of `latchkey' children as families were no longer able to afford before and/or after school care. Many witnesses voiced concerns about the safety and welfare of primary age children left to look after themselves.

The Committee considers that OSHC services should have greater access to school facilities. Where services must amalgamate and children are required to travel from schools to the service, funding should be provided to ensure that the cost of travel is not an increased burden on families.

A further matter raised in evidence was that Childcare Assistance is calculated taking into account only the number of children in the family using a particular service type. The Committee considers that the justification for not taking into account all service types used by a family in calculating Childcare Assistance should be investigated further.

The Committee considers that vacation care services face similar problems to OSHC services regarding administrative costs and fluctuating attendance. The Committee considers that additional funding for administrative costs should be extended to vacation care services.

The Committee concludes that FDC offers an important additional choice for families seeking care for their children, in particular for those with special needs such as shift workers, those requiring overnight and respite care and for families in rural and remote Australia. The operational subsidy is a fundamental element of the FDC system and no changes should be made to this arrangement.

Much of the evidence on the impact on families emphasised the changes to affordability of child care, particularly for low-income families. Anecdotal evidence suggested that affordability of child care has declined and that many families are withdrawing children from formal care or choosing to mix formal and informal care arrangements or changing work arrangements to limit the cost of child care for the family.

The Committee considers that while Government assistance has not increased at the same rate as increases in child care costs for families, the impact on affordability has varied across income ranges. The Committee considers that there has been minimal impact on affordability of child care for high-income earners. The Committee received much contradictory anecdotal evidence in relation to affordability for middle-income earners. However, it considers, for the moment at least, that middle-income earners are able to access child care without too much economic difficulty. In relation to low-income earners the picture is different and the Committee considers that there has been a much more significant decline in affordability. This is having an adverse impact on the ability of low-income families to access formal child care, particularly those families with more than one child. The Committee has therefore recommended that urgent action be taken to better target child care assistance to low-income families by the introduction of a `top up' or `supplement' to the current rate of Childcare Assistance.

The Committee also recommends that the Department Family and Community Services conduct research to establish criteria to judge affordability levels for families accessing child care as a matter of priority.

The Committee considers that the impact of changes to child care funding on children has not been adequately assessed, in particular any changes to quality of care. The Committee has recommended that the review of the Quality Improvement and Accreditation System (QIAS) being undertaken by the Child Care Advisory Council be completed as a matter of priority.

In relation to informal care, the Committee recognises that informal care will always be the most favoured option for many parents. However, the Committee also notes that informal care, by its nature, is largely unregulated and that in some instances it may not provide the same benefits and protection as formal care for children and their families. Further, there are some families who are forced to choose informal care because of affordability and access issues.

para.inline: Families in rural and remote areas and disadvantaged families

speech.para: While the Government has provided additional funding assistance through its Disadvantaged Areas Subsidy, there is a need for further assistance for disadvantaged families living in urban areas. The Committee believes that the range of services to which the Disadvantaged Area Subsidy applies is too restrictive. Many urban centres provide important services and benefits for particularly high-needs families. The Committee considers that this should be recognised and supported through additional funding. The Committee has recommended that additional funding be provided to centres which cater for very high needs families in socially or economically disadvantaged urban areas.

Several groups and individuals expressed the view during the inquiry that parents should be given the widest possible choice to either participate in the paid workforce or remain in full-time care of their children and that universal child care payments to all families with young children be introduced. The Committee has some reservations in relation to this proposal. These reservations relate to the potentially significant additional budgetary costs of such a scheme, and the possibility that funds would be spread too thinly across the potential target group. However, the Committee has recommended that the costs required to implement any proposal to introduce universal child care payments to all families with young children be investigated to ascertain whether such a proposal could be at all viable.

The Committee received a considerable amount of anecdotal evidence suggesting that recent fee increases and changes in the child care sector are having an adverse impact on women's participation in the paid workforce. While the published labour force data do not appear to reflect these trends to date, the Committee believes that the full impact of the changes has yet to be reflected in these official statistics and that some decline in women's labour force participation rates will become evident in official labour force data in subsequent years.

para.inline: Impact on workers in the child care sector

speech.para: The Committee considers that child care workers have been detrimentally affected by the changes which have been occurring in the child care industry. They have suffered job losses, and reduced working hours, wages, conditions of service and career development opportunities. They are lowly paid and working in difficult conditions. Professional recognition should be given to the valuable contribution provided by these workers in managing the physical, emotional and intellectual development of children in their care. As one submission noted, next to parents, it is with the children's services workers that `the greatest responsibility for the care and education of the youngest and most vulnerable members of our society rests'.
Finally I commend the report and its recommendations to the Government.

talk.start.para: —I also wish to address a few remarks to this Senate Community Affairs References Committee report on child-care funding. It provides a very useful addition to the information available on what is occurring in child care under the Howard government, and I think it will be an important reference source for people in years to come.

speech.para: What is most clear is that this report proves what parents, community groups and the industry have known all along: that, under the Howard government, child care has become more difficult to afford. The government has taken $850 million out of child care, and assistance has been frozen at $115 per week. But many centres have had to raise their fees, which average now around $150 per week. As a result the gap between the assistance provided and the fees charged has widened, with many parents struggling in affording to cover that increasing gap.

The child-care cuts of Mr Howard's government have been very tough on household budgets. In particular, they have been very tough on women and their ability to participate fully in the work force and in education in this country. Many women have reported—and the evidence is in the committee report—that they have had to give up work, they have had to give up educational opportunities or they have had to restrict their participation because of the increasing cost burden of affording child care. That is something that the community and this Senate must take very seriously.

The government went to the last election with a promise to increase child-care assistance by a very small amount of $750 extra for each child in care. But that does not seem to have been proved to be a priority for the government, and we have seen no sign of that legislation. I suspect that that reflects the government's lack of priority for child care.

I was not a member of the committee at the time of the report, but I did take the opportunity to fill in for Senator Gibbs for a couple of days and was able to attend a couple of days of the hearings, which I found very useful. It was part of my ongoing interest in child care, and that interest has been both as a consumer and as a parliamentarian. I am very pleased now to be involved in the Community Affairs Reference Committee. I cannot claim to have been involved in the whole of the inquiry or the drafting of the report but in recent weeks I have been involved with the committee's work.

I believe that the key issues arising from this report are worth while for all of us to consider. The affordability question is the key issue; it is having the most impact out there in the community. The increasing affordability impacts on the parents; they are forced to reduce their care or withdraw their children from care altogether. That, of course, then impacts on the centres. In recent years we have seen a large number of centres having to close, and that is documented fully in the committee report.

There is some restructuring occurring in the industry, and some of the changes are driven by other factors. The report quite rightly acknowledges that—that there has been some quite uncontrolled growth, in particular in Queensland and a number of other states. But that is not the only factor at work. The affordability question is driving a lot of the closures and a lot of the reduced demand in the sector. That is something that is directly attributable to government policy and the increasing costs of child care.

So there are a number of issues here and a number of developments occurring in the industry. But, as I have said, the affordability issue is at the core of a lot of the development in the industry, it is at the core of a lot of the problems of the parents, and, therefore, it is at the core of a lot of the problems for child-care centres.

The report particularly recommends development of a child-care assistance supplement for low income earners. I think that is a very interesting development. The committee spent a lot of energy looking at better targeting of child-care assistance for low income families, particularly those with more than one child. The committee has recognised that the impact of the Howard government cutbacks to child care and the failure to increase assistance have impacted disproportionately on low income families and reduced their ability to afford child care. We are seeing in a whole range of areas that child-care centres seem to be closing in disadvantaged locations, far more so than they are in the more well to do suburbs.

In my own state of Western Australia, I have had a recent experience with a Voogalari child-care centre in Langford, an area that is not well-to-do. That centre has been unable to get assistance under the disadvantaged area subsidy provided by the government because it is not a rural or regional centre. It is an urban centre, but it is a centre whose client base is predominantly of families with working class parents or parents who are on income support.

So I think my own experience in Western Australia confirms what the committee report finds, which is that there is a real problem here about the lack of sufficiency of child-care assistance to those families in low income areas, and we are seeing that impact on child-care centres in those areas. I think the recommendations of the committee's report really do require the government to have a good look at that issue and at directing more assistance to enable child care still to be an option for low income families who need that sort of assistance.

I think there is a really interesting discussion to be had, too, about the survival of the community based system of child care in this country. The report recognises the importance of the sector, it describes the damage and it provides some interesting suggestions as possible solutions.

I think the really good thing about the report is that it does recognise that, on the issue of child care, there is more than market economics at stake in the community. We have to value other things. We have to give some recognition to social values in our considerations. The committee is to be commended for its recommendations that go to supporting a mixed private/community sector based model of child care in this country and for its recommendation that we ought to find new ways of supporting that community endeavour.

Community sector child care provides us with social values and community infrastructure that are at the heart of healthy communities, and there has to be a role for those community based child care centres. They are under enormous pressure as a result of the abolition of operational subsidies. They are among the centres struggling to survive in those changed circumstances, and the committee recommends special support for those centres. They do not recommend reintroducing the operational subsidy, but they do recognise not only the special needs but also the role that those centres play. They recognise that that is a contribution that we as a community ought to value and support. I think that is another very encouraging part of the report.

There is a very good section on out-of-school-hours care. I do not have time to discuss that at length, but I think there are very real concerns about what has happened to out-of-school-hours care and vacation care as a result of the government's cutbacks. I know from my own experience in Western Australia that large numbers of centres have closed and other centres are really struggling. This is an important area of child care that has been very badly hit by the government's policy decisions. It is an area of child care that runs on a shoestring and provides a very essential service for working parents. It is an area that we ought to be supporting. The committee report correctly identifies that that sector has been driven down and very badly affected by government policy changes.

There are other issues that I want to mention just briefly. One issue is the discussion and report on the impact on women, which I mentioned before. This is a really important social issue. We have to provide support for families where both parents want to work or single parent families where that parent wants to work. It is a wasted resource if people are driven out of the work force and their skills and abilities are not used. It also denies them the proper opportunities in life that we should be allowing them. It is a very important issue.

The other issue is the discussion of the impacts on child-care workers. They are a group that provides an enormous contribution to our society, are very poorly paid and have very poor conditions, and the government's policy changes have worsened their conditions quite considerably as more pressure has been put on the centres. I think the discussion in the report about the need to support those workers is a very important aspect of the report as well.

talk.start.para: —In a moment I am going to seek leave to incorporate my speech rather than take up the time of the Senate, but I will do that in the hope that I might also get leave to very briefly return to the report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Committee, so that I can present that.
—Senator, you can do that after this is disposed of.
—I seek leave to incorporate my speech on this issue in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
Child Care Funding Report
This inquiry into child care funding, which was established to examine the impact of changes introduced by the Coalition during its first term, was a timely one.
The more than one thousand submissions received by the committee and the testimony the committee heard highlighted a number of problems with the current approach to child care.

It is clear to the Democrats that there is an urgent need for changes which will address the negative way the Government's current child care policies are impacting on children, parents and child care providers.
The child care industry has suffered greatly and the choices available to Australia's families have been greatly reduced under the Coalition Government.
Not only has the Coalition failed families, it has also failed small business.
Many private and community child care centres are now experiencing very hard times. A number of centres have already closed.
These problems have been caused by changes introduced in the 1996 Budget which have increased the out of pocket cost of child care services for a large number of families.
These changes have resulted in a growing number of parents turning to unregulated backyard care or grandparents or friends to care for their children.
Going into the 1996 election the Coalition talked a lot about its commitment to small business. In Government it has also had a lot to say about the important role this sector plays in the economy.
However, this Government's so called `commitment' to small business rings very hollow in the light of the effect its child care policies are having on private child care centre operators.
Over the past six months my child care adviser and I have met a number of centre owners who have had to sell their family home just to remain in business.
We have met people whose marriages have broken down under the pressure of falling occupancy rates and we have met others who have been forced to seek professional help for depression.

Many private centre owners have told us they are now just so desperate to cut their losses and walk away from their businesses altogether but cannot do so because child care centres are no longer saleable items.
Yet this Government has largely refused to acknowledge the way its policies have affected families and child care operators.

It has, instead, chosen to blame the current problems on the former Labor Government's failure to introduce appropriate planning mechanisms and the uncontrolled growth of centres which occurred as a consequence.
Claims that oversupply have contributed to the current crisis in child care are, of course, supported by the Democrats.
However, we are convinced that the current situation has been primarily caused by changes introduced in the 1996 Budget.
Perhaps one of the most disturbing impacts of the Coalition's child care policies is the rapid growth which has occurred in unregulated backyard care.

The Democrats firmly believe this practice must be stopped as soon as possible both to protect the safety of Australia's children and to ensure that there is a viable future for high-quality, formal child care in this country.

At the moment those offering unregulated backyard care can register as being eligible for the Childcare Rebate. This means that parents using these services can claim Childcare Rebate to offset their fees.
Yet these informal backyard carers are not subject to any character checks, safety checks or any other form of quality control.

While the Government says it supports all families' child care choices, the Democrats believe it is crucial to differentiate between children who are cared for by trusted relatives or friends and those who are being cared for by carers who are completely unchecked and unregulated.
We support the removal of Childcare Rebate eligibility for those providing informal, backyard child care as a priority.
The Democrats recommend the following changes, which were formulated in close consultation with parents and child care operators throughout the country, to the Coalition's current childcare policies:
. immediately raise the level of Childcare Assistance available to families from $2.30 to $2.70 per hour;
. increase the Childcare Assistance ceiling for out of school hours care services so that it is in line with that which is paid to families using similar services through family day care;
. increase the 20 hour limit on non-work related care to three full days of care;
. remove the 50 hour cap on Childcare Assistance for work related care;
. remove Childcare Rebate eligibility for those providing informal, unregulated backyard child care; and
. continue with the current arrangements for the provision of operational subsidies for family day care services.
The Democrats believe that the maintenance of proper childcare is one of the most pressing issues for families in Australia today.

talk.start.para: —In less than 10 minutes, I wish to make a few comments concerning the report of the Senate Community Affairs References Committee on child-care funding. I was the chairman of that committee, and it was a most interesting, useful and—one hopes—in the long run helpful inquiry.

speech.para: There is no doubt, as Senator Evans said in his comments, that the changes, alterations, cutbacks and different priorities of this government in the area of child-care funding have had significant impact in all states of Australia. There has been a shift in the marketplace. There has been a shift towards demands for a different type of child care and there has been a shift in growth patterns in the private sector as opposed to the community sector.

We went on the road for some eight or nine days to all mainland states. The format of the committee was quite useful in that we had the opportunity to hear evidence from hundreds and hundreds of people in addition to the some 900 or 1,000 submissions received by the committee. The format in nearly every state was that there would be an hour-long session where parents could come along and make a short three-minute statement addressing issues or concerns arising from changes to child-care funding. Then there was another hour-long session where operators in both the community sector and the private sector came along and put their focus. This enabled the committee and all the senators participating to come to terms immediately with the real issues faced by parents of children and by the operators in the community and private sectors in this key industry.

What was interesting at the outset was that there was a range of divergent and, I sadly conclude, almost irreconcilable different philosophical approaches to this whole issue of child-care funding from those who regard it purely as a labour market device to encourage females to participate in the work force to those at the other end of the spectrum who regard child raising as something purely to be done by mothers who want to stay at home and which the states should pay—apparently, large sums of money—for. In the range of community fora and discussions that were hosted by the committee there appeared to be a range of views that go right across the spectrum, and unfortunately there appeared also to be little capacity for those views to come together and concentrate on the real interests of parents and children.

To that extent, when the secretariat was given the drafting instructions to bring the massive material and evidence together, the instruction was to have a bias towards low income families, families with dependent children and for the report to seek to achieve practical measures to give equity to low income families and families in disadvantaged or depressed areas. To that extent, the report accurately reflects the evidence received by the committee and the work done by the committee.

There is no doubt that in the community sector and the private sector—basically an industry exclusively dominated by small business, there not yet having been a consolidation into chain operations—there is enormous commitment by the operators of those centres and enormous commitment by the parents and the workers who give their time in those centres to the children who are managed there.

Chapter 3 in the report has a wealth of information in both statistical form and in an analysis by the secretariat as to child-care use in Australia, numbers of centres, numbers of parents, funds expended by government, and trends over time. For someone coming new to this area I would suggest this wealth of information can only help in the future. So that was the view that was brought by those participating in the committee.

I was somewhat surprised when I read the minority report from Senators Sue Knowles and Marise Payne. I think it is fair to say that they did not bring, perhaps, the open mind to this debate on child care that might have been appropriate. I must say that during the hearings my views on the issue of child care changed quite radically, from the evidence provided by parents, child-care operators and the various submissions made, particularly by the department. The minority report by Senators Knowles and Payne, if one wanted to describe it, is a churlish minority report. It adds little value to the mass of information gained. It provides no objective analysis and to some extent provides petty and petulant comment from the government senators. I am at a loss to know why they went out of their way to provide five pages of comment along those lines.

The case is similar with the report by Senator Bartlett, from the Democrats. I was surprised that he authored the report, it having been Senator Woodley from my memory who participated in the hearings, certainly in the Queensland hearings, and who was the person I had some involvement with on the committee. Senator Bartlett, apparently, has responsibility for child care in the Democrats. I pass no comment on that. The problem is that when you have someone writing a dissenting report who has not, to my knowledge, participated in the inquiry as such and heard from the hundreds of witnesses who bother to come forward, they bring their own preconceived ideas or notions to their report. To some extent it reflects inbuilt biases. That seems to be a recurring theme. I have been asked to conclude my remarks. I seek leave to continue my remarks on this report later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: —This evening I would like to speak about a matter that is of interest to my constituents in the Northern Territory and probably to many other Australians. That issue is the recent failed referendum relating to the proposal for statehood in the Northern Territory. This is an interesting and informative story that illustrates the attitude of the government in the Northern Territory. It was not that long ago that public opinion polls showed public support for Northern Territory statehood running at about 80 per cent. However, when the statehood referendum was held recently, nearly 53 per cent of Territorians voted against statehood. That is a remarkable and disturbing turnaround in public support over a relatively short time.

speech.para: Today I want to put on the public record what happened with that push for statehood, identify where the push for statehood went wrong and look at who is to blame for this unexpected and unprecedented result. Since the Northern Territory was granted self-government in 1978, talk about statehood has never been far off the local political agenda. It has waxed and waned depending on how close the Territory was to either a federal or Territory election.

In 1985, a bipartisan committee of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly was established to look at the issue of statehood for the Territory and how best to pursue it. Over the last decade or so, this committee, the Sessional Committee on Constitutional Development, has been active in consulting the wider community about what would be included in any new constitution if statehood were granted.

In 1986, a three-pronged process of constitution building was adopted by the Country Liberal Party, led by the then Chief Minister, Steve Hatton. This process included the development of a draft constitution by a bipartisan committee of the Legislative Assembly, the consideration of that document by a constitutional convention and ratification by the Legislative Assembly with its submission for approval to a referendum. The committee presented its final report in November 1996.

It should be pointed out that the CLP member and former Chief Minister Steve Hatton, who has overseen the Territory's development towards statehood as head of the Sessional Committee on Constitutional Development, embraced the idea of an elected people's convention and an inclusive process. However, as we will see, these concepts were not in keeping with the desire of the current Chief Minister, Shane Stone, to push statehood through with what many people have described as almost indecent haste.

In April 1995, the then Prime Minister, Paul Keating, agreed to the establishment of a joint Commonwealth-Northern Territory working group to examine and report on the implications of statehood for the Northern Territory. It is fair to say that the push for statehood received further impetus when the federal parliament decided to overrule the Northern Territory's euthanasia legislation. This reminded many Territorians that they did not enjoy the same level of rights as the states.

A constitutional convention was held in Darwin in late March this year to consider the final draft constitution which would give shape to any new state created by the granting of statehood. The convention got off to a controversial start. None of the 54 delegates for the constitutional convention were directly or popularly elected. Instead, the Northern Territory government hand-picked them. It is true to say that particular people representing particular community groups were elected, but those community groups were chosen by the Northern Territory government.

Aboriginal Territorians were also unhappy with the constitutional convention. The Northern and Central Land Councils boycotted the convention, angry at the lack of representation offered to them at the convention by the CLP government. They argued—quite correctly, I think—that as they represented over 65,000 people they deserved more than one place between two councils.

The CLP government managed to push through their preferred constitution, overlooking many of the recommendations arising from the Sessional Committee on Constitu tional Development's lengthy process of community consultation. Another outcome was that the convention recommended three referendum questions. These questions were: whether people supported statehood, what the new name of the state should be and whether people supported the draft constitution. However, on 18 August this year, the Chief Minister, Shane Stone, rejected that proposal for three referendum questions, announcing that it had been decided that only one question should be submitted to voters in the referendum. That question, which was subsequently put to voters on 3 October, was:

Now that a constitution for a State of the Northern Territory has been recommended by the Statehood Convention and endorsed by the Northern Territory Parliament:- Do you agree that we should become a state? Yes/No.

In what was considered to be a shock result, nearly 53 per cent of Territorians voted against the statehood proposal. But statehood should have been assured. It had bipartisan support from both the CLP and the ALP in the Northern Territory. However, the ALP support was qualified. The Territory ALP was unhappy with the way the CLP had tried to hijack the statehood process for their own political objectives. Anyone who questioned any aspect of the statehood process was dismissed by the arrogant CLP as being anti-Territorian. The oldest trick in the book up in the Territory is that, if anyone questions the way you are doing something, you label them as being anti-Territorian—something akin to being accused of heresy.

In response to public concerns about the proposed draft constitution in the lead-up to the statehood referendum, Chief Minister Shane Stone, at his dismissive best, said that if people did not like the draft constitution then they should simply vote against statehood—the implication being that they would be committing a treasonable act. However, many people on both sides of the political fence took the Chief Minister at his word, announcing that they would be voting against statehood, not because they were opposed to statehood but because they were not happy about the contents of the draft constitution or because they were not sure what was contained in the constitution and what it meant.

Territorians were given the opportunity to closely examine the draft constitution only a few weeks before the referendum. Then, in what was a massive turnaround, the Chief Minister changed tack and said that if people did not like the draft constitution they should not vote against statehood. He said there would be plenty of opportunities for further consultation about the content of the constitution after the referendum on statehood. The referendum was no longer about the constitution; it was solely about statehood.

He did not really give people much choice. He said, `Trust me. Vote for statehood and I will take into account your concerns about the constitution after the referendum'—after Territorians had voted on statehood. He was hoping, I suspect, that Territorians would give their imprimatur to statehood while not supporting the draft constitution. However, as we have seen, the majority of Territorians—prompted, I think, by the experiences of many Territorians on both sides of the political fence—realised that trusting the Chief Minister was a precarious exercise and subsequently voted against statehood.

In short, a referendum on statehood, which should have breezed through, which should have collected up a celebration of people in the Northern Territory and which should have been a step in the history of the Northern Territory, was defeated—not because the overwhelming majority of Territorians were opposed to statehood but because they did not trust the process. They did not trust what they were being asked to do. And who can blame them? It should be pointed out that there was no constitutional necessity for a referendum on statehood and, under section 121 of the Australian Constitution, the federal parliament has the power to establish a new state.

In another classic display of bad faith, the Territory parliament refused to fund both the `yes' and `no' cases for the referendum. While it is perhaps true that they were not obliged to fund both sides, it showed a lack of goodwill in funding only the `yes' case. The amount spent on the `yes' case was substantial: $600,000 was spent on advertising and another $160,000 was spent by the Territory electoral commission on distributing the official `yes' case. It was left to a coalition of concerned groups, under the auspices of Territorians for Democratic Statehood, to draw the attention of Territorians to the failings and inadequacies of the argument in favour of statehood. They did this with minimal resources. I think they spent around $7,000 and presented their arguments very well.

What lessons have we learned from the statehood debacle? I do not believe that the referendum result reflected people's actual feelings on statehood. People were clearly unhappy with the way the statehood process was undertaken, and they were not happy with the man attempting to crash statehood through.

Last week in Batchelor, over 120 indigenous delegates from the Territory were meeting to discuss what they wanted to include in any constitution to accompany statehood, and the conclusions from the Batchelor College conference are on the public record. I was disturbed to hear that the Chief Minister was invited to attend that constitutional convention and clearly did not bother to do so.

In concluding, the statehood process must be inclusive in the Territory. Territorians want an opportunity to have a constitutional convention with democratically elected representatives. They want a constitution which ensures accountable government in the Territory and they want a constitution which accurately reflects their inspirations and protects their interests. I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of my speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Likewise, Aboriginal Territorians want a constitution which protects their cultural, political, religious and social rights.

When these things are addressed I am confident that Territorians will be overwhelmingly supportive of statehood and I would hope that the Australian parliament would then support the Northern Territory becoming the seventh state of Australia.

talk.start.para: —With your indulgence, Madam President, as a brief synopsis, I would like to continue where I left off on Monday night with respect to the Federal Court judgment by Justice Malcolm Lee, which in effect gave 7,199 square kilometres of land to the 28 claimants who were listed in that judgment. I want to make sure that my fellow Australians are aware of the serious ramifications that that judgment had—not just for my state of Western Australia but for the nation of Australia as a whole. Unless it is handled very succinctly and with immense circumspection, I fear that that one single judgment—the first made by a court in Australia—will have serious ramifications for Australia both economically and socially.

speech.para: The land that was granted covers an area, as I said, of over 7,000 square kilometres in the Kununurra region of the East Kimberley and extends into the Northern Territory. It includes freehold land, Lake Argyle, historic and other pastoral leases, vacant crown land, the Ord River, the Kununurra town site itself and various reserves and special leases. In his judgment, Justice Lee said that it did, inter alia, cover:

. . . a right to make decisions about the use and enjoyment of the determination area; . . . a right to control the access of others to the determination area; a right to use and enjoy resources of the determination area; a right to control the use and enjoyment of others of resources of the determination area; . . . a right to receive a portion of any resources taken by others from the determination area.

This will not be the first of what is going to happen in Western Australia, which is of vital concern to me and, as a result, to the nation. In 1901, Australia became an indissoluble federation of states, but it appears that it is not completely indissoluble because parts now are being taken out of it—50 per cent or more of the Northern Territory, for instance, is controlled by indigenous people.

Western Australia also has areas that are controlled by indigenous people for their exclusive use. The Pitjantjatjara people in the central part of Australia also have exclusive use of an area of land that is the size of France, and one needs to have a permit to get through that area unless one is driving on the roads. It is of vital concern to me that a nation that has had no boundaries in common with anyone else other than Australians is being carved up in the form of apartheid, if you like, in reverse.

Japan has its aboriginal people in the form of the Ainu, who reside solely now in the northern part of Hokkaido, which is itself the northernmost main island of the Japanese archipelago. India has its people, the Dravidians, who never had any land rights there, in the southern part of India. There are little or no land rights in South America. South Africa had its Hottentots, who are extinct in their pure form but who are reflected in many of the Cape coloureds, who make a wonderful contribution both to their cultural remnants as well as to their hard work and ingenuity in that country. The bushmen of South Africa are a credit to their survival. Against all sorts of odds they have survived in small pockets of what was formerly South-West Africa.

I think that the problems we are facing now are minuscule compared with what they will be in the future. Australia relies on exports for its survival. The mining industry—in which I have spent a great deal of my life after having studied geology in Kalgoorlie and worked in the exploration and mining industry—exports last fiscal year were worth $40.8 billion. A great deal of that came from Western Australia. It contributed in direct taxes $1.2 billion. It contributed in indirect taxes in excess of a further half a billion dollars. This fiscal year, 1997-98, for the first time in 50 years there was a retreat of seven per cent in the amount of money that was spent on exploration. We are, in effect, living off yesterday's discoveries. The health of Western Australia is the health of the nation.

As I said in my speech on Monday night, Western Australia produces 27½ per cent of national export income. We are being thwarted as a result of the decision by the Federal Court two weeks ago of having mineral rights now that are naturally reserved for the Crown. The 38 per cent of Western Australia which is pastoral lease is crown land for the purpose of the WA Mining Act—not so native title. Native title today includes the minerals. So, with a wave of his judicial wand, Justice Lee has created, I suppose, a hunter-gatherer people into miners, tourist operators and so on. That is causing, and will cause, immense disruption to established industries wherever native title is imposed.

I have a duty, as every member in this House has a duty, to scrutinise any decisions made by any court. I find that the decision made by Justice Lee is detrimental to Western Australia, and I know it is because I have been in consultation with the Western Australian Farmers Federation, the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies, the Chamber of Minerals and Energy and the Pastoralists and Graziers Association—and I have been a member of some of those organisations for many years. They are fearful about this precedent set by the Federal Court.

No judge, in my humble opinion—as the Lord Protector Oliver Cromwell said in the first part of the 17th century—is above the law; no-one is as tall as that. Judges themselves cannot be above criticism. They interpret the law, and some people have said in recent times they are making the law. They cannot be above criticism. I do not propose to be silent, and nor will I be silent, on matters that affect my state of Western Australia.

We are yet to define native title unambiguously. I am not sure what native title is. I do know it is better than fee simple. I do know it is better than perpetual leases. I do know it is better than conditional purchase. I do know it is better than pastoral leases. It is a title that appears to me to be something akin to the old English titles where, in theory, you had a plot of land on a surface area that extended in a wedge to the centre of the earth and you had that which covered the birds of the air as well. That is what appears to me to be native title.

What I do know is that you need a permit to get into these places. We now have frontiers in Australia where you need a permit to enter—or you can call it a visa, if you like. I have had to apply for visas myself, even as a member of parliament, to get into those lands. I am seriously disturbed about the ramifica tions this will have and is having on pastoral families, some of whom have been there for five generations. I am seriously concerned about that.

I have said that I have a profound duty to my state of Western Australia and I take representing that state here very seriously. Unless some legal sanity prevails in this most vexing period of our national evolvement, we will witness not only an economic downturn but also the division of Australia—apartheid in reverse, as I have mentioned—and all of those social and other aspects of it that would create upheavals we have never had before. I ask my colleagues to take serious note of the judgment that Justice Malcolm Lee made two weeks ago in the Federal Court and how it affects our state of Western Australia and thus the rest of the nation.

subdebateinfo.title: Native Title: Miriuwong and Gajerrong Decision
East Timor

talk.start.para: —It seems like One Nation got into the Senate before it got here, judging from that diatribe we just heard from the honourable senator opposite who referred to cultural remnants. I hope that speech is an expression of a cultural remnant in this country. The senator did not even understand that it is not up to the courts to grant things; it is up to the courts to interpret the law made by the parliament. That is what His Honour Justice Lee did in the Federal Court, and I would have thought it would have been far more dignified of the senator to come in here and back the right of the judge to make that determination according to the law.

speech.para: I might also say to Senator Lightfoot—through you, Madam President—that when entering Tasmania the situation is worse, because you do not need just a visa or entry permit. You have to get a key to enter indigenous lands in Tasmania, but you do not go to the indigenous Tasmanians to get it—you go to the woodchip corporations. They determine whether or not you can get a key to go into large areas of Tasmania which they have locked up. They determine what time you can come out and so on.

What we have seen in this country is a move away from the rights of indigenous people to the superseding rights of corporate nonentities—faceless people in the corporate sector ruling over who can and who cannot go here and there. Try to go into the Jabiluka valley at the moment and see what ERA confronts you with—and that is indigenous land. The senator who just spoke does not understand that, right around this planet, the time-honoured right of indigenous people to their land has been usurped by the sheer power of the corporate sector over successive governments. They have taken away the rights of the older owners, supplanted themselves in there and are determining what happens to too much of this magnificent country of ours.

I want to speak about governments, because one of the most difficult things for us to tackle in the coming years will be our relationship with the people of East Timor. It is very difficult to talk about this matter as a member of parliament without implying that, in some way or other, it is a criticism of this country of ours. I want to make it clear from the outset that the criticism goes to the governments of this country, rather than the people of this country, and there is a very important distinction to be made there.

This afternoon the government voted in the Senate with Senator Colston to turn down a motion I put forward which called on the government to offer whatever help it could to the Habibie administration in Indonesia in its investigation into the wealth of President Suharto et al. So we see the latest episode in a failure of responsibility by our government to look over the fence in a way which is constructive to our neighbours—by that, I mean the people of Indonesia rather than the government of Indonesia.

I want to refer this evening to one Australian who has faithfully documented the plight of East Timor and sought to confront what he calls Australia's culpability in the East Timor genocide—that is Jim Aubrey, the executive spokesman of Australians for a Free East Timor. I want to quote from his book Free East Timor and an essay he more recently prepared for Geneva. In his book Free East Timor are these words:

The depth of the Australian Government's acquiescence to and appeasement of Jakarta's intentions, and Canberra's accommodation of the Indonesian regime's crimes against humanity, begin in full earnest with the murder, on 16 October 1975, of five Australian and Australian-based television journalists. Having gone to East Timor to find out the truth behind the accusations concerning Indonesian plans to invade East Timor, they were brutally murdered by Indonesian soldiers, whom it appears had crossed the border with the singular purpose of eliminating the newsmen. Canberra's reaction was not only silence but, as well, an unquestioning and subservient acceptance of Jakarta's explanation that the newsmen had died in cross-fire during a battle with East Timorese soldiers. Canberra—
meaning the Australian government of the day—

displayed a greater common allegiance with the criminal murderers than with its own murdered citizens, and Indonesia readily saw that it could act in East Timor with impunity. On the fate of the journalists, eyewitness testimonies now in existence totally contradict the Canberra-Jakarta `cross-fire theory', rejecting the suggestion that any fighting took place on the morning of the murders.
Mr Aubrey went on to say:

On 7 December Indonesia invaded East Timor and two months after the invasion, 60,000 East Timorese had perished—the same number of East Timorese that are believed to have died in Australia's war against Japan in the 1940s.

On the opening days of the invasion, several hundred civilian men, women and children, including another Australian journalist, were shot, one by one, on the wharf in Dili harbour. One eye witness reported that `the Indonesians tore the crying children from their mothers and passed them back to the crowd. The women were shot one by one, with the onlookers being ordered by the Indonesians to count.

Australia signed an exploration agreement with Indonesia in 1989 to exploit the billion dollar oil and gas field of the East Timor Gap. By this time well over one-third of the East Timorese population had perished under the Indonesian occupation. That amounts to more than a quarter of a million people. For his part, Mr Whitlam went uninvited in 1983 to the United Nations in an attempt to persuade the general assembly to drop East Timor from its agenda. He was not successful and to this day he remains recalcitrant to the extreme about being unable to condemn the indiscriminate violence against the civilian population of East Timor. Mr Aubrey states:

The position of each of the successive Australian Governments is more than criminal negligence. It is direct complicity in genocide. Consecutive Australian governments have perpetuated their compliant mimicry to the physical, cultural and ethnic genocide in East Timor. The successor to Gough Whitlam, conservative Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser, made Australia the first Western country to grant recognition to the annexation of East Timor, which was further supported and clarified by Fraser's successor, Labor leader Bob Hawke. The next Prime Minister, new Labor leader Paul Keating, expressly went to Washington in September 1993, at a time when American human rights endeavours were being finetuned, with the result that a number of restrictions were placed upon defence sales and defence training to Jakarta. Mr Keating urged President Clinton to withdraw human rights considerations from underpinning economic and defence contracts. In 1995, the Keating Government awarded the Order of Australia to the Indonesian Foreign Affairs Minister, Ali Alatas, at a time when many countries in the world were giving peace awards to Bishop Belo and Jose Ramos Horta.
We then read at the end of this book a quote from Greg Shackleton, who was one of the Channel 7 crew from Melbourne killed in October 1975. In his last on-camera report, he said, in part:
. . . Something happened here that moved us very deeply. It was so far outside our experience as Australians that we'll find it very difficult to convey to you, but we'll try.

Sitting on woven mats, under a thatched roof, in a hut with no walls, we were the target of a barrage of questioning from men who know they may die tomorrow and cannot understand why the rest of the world does not care. That's all they want: for the United Nations to care about what is happening here. The emotion here last night was so strong that we, all three of us, felt we should be able to reach out into the warm night air and touch it.

It was an appeal to Australia that went unheard. The death of Mr Shackleton and his fellow crew members on the subsequent day was a murder which has gone unanalysed and unpunished. I want to add a quote which Mr Aubrey draws attention to from Xanana Gusmao, the East Timorese resistance leader still in gaol in Jakarta. He said in 1990:
We have to say that Australia has taken an attitude of an accomplice in the genocide perpetrated by the occupation forces.

I hope that in the coming year the inquiries which have been established in this place will do something not only to redress the unspeakable wrongs that have occurred to our East Timorese neighbour but also to in some way assuage the complicity of successive Australian governments in what has happened.

talk.start.para: —This evening I wish to address the revolution that is happening on Australia's waterfront—in particular the Melbourne waterfront, where the Senate will recall the tumultuous union strike which occurred last April. It is fair to say that industrial warfare broke out at this time as Patrick Stevedoring, backed by the government and aligned with P&C Stevedores, took on the Maritime Union of Australia to bring about desperately needed reforms to productivity.

speech.para: It is worthy to note the state of Australia's wharves prior to the strike. To this end, I refer to a speech I made on 26 October 1997 outlining the inefficiencies of Australia's waterfront. Firstly, our crane rates were some of the worst in the world, with a five port average of 18 containers per hour. Secondly, there were truck turnaround times averaging 1.5 hours; again, this was one of the worst, compared with the best practice times of 30 minutes. Thirdly, rorts were occurring in actual hours worked, such as the notorious `nick', meaning that you went home early—you nicked off. There was payment for 22 hours on a Sunday for 4.5 hours of work. Fourthly, the industrial action on the waterfront was 10 times higher than that of any other industry in Australia. That was one of the worst, if not the worst, rates in the world.

Each productivity benchmark was supported by a number of inquiries undertaken either by the government's Productivity Commission or independent sources. There was no avoiding the facts. We had the worst wharves in the world and something had to be done. The level of performance at Australia's container terminals is particularly vital to Australia's agricultural traders, with containerised cargo representing 66 per cent of the value of Australia's seagoing imports and 40 per cent of the total value of exports. In 1995-96 some $62 billion of cargo was shipped in containers.

The task the government had to undertake was never going to be easy, given the entrenched interests and historical resistance of the Maritime Workers Union. Nevertheless, the government's open objectives were to meet seven benchmarks for reform: firstly, an end to over-manning and restrictive work practices; secondly, higher productivity through 25 crane lifts per hour; thirdly, greater reliability through less industrial disruption and less interruption through elimination of restrictive work practices; fourthly, substantial improvements in the industry's appalling occupational health and safety performance; fifthly, lower costs through the ports logistic chain; sixthly, introduction of new technology; and, seventhly, training.

These benchmarks were backed up by the government's industrial legislation, particularly the re-introduction of the secondary boycott law. I do not wish to trawl over the events of the dispute that consequently broke out. We recall the players. They were the National Farmers Federation's P&C Stevedores, Patricks, the MUA and the government. Of course, we recall the vitriol and the threats and lies that flew from the union. Australia caught international attention at this time with pictures of workers being dragged from picket lines, children being used as front-line strikers and balaclavaed security men, none of it doing Australia's international reputation any favours. Such was the price that all parties were willing to pay to win.

Enough time has elapsed to assess the results of the agreement reached between Patricks and the MUA that saw the dispute end and the MUA return to work. What has emerged is a remarkable improvement on the docks. First, turnaround times for trucks in Melbourne are now only 20 minutes, which is as low as they get anywhere in the world. Second, Patricks has reduced manning levels by 50 per cent. Third, there have been more than 100 changes to work practices and conditions and the legendary rorts. Fourth, an 800-page agreement has been reduced to 36 pages. Fifth, a number of tasks have been outsourced, such as the maintenance of plant and equipment. Sixth, where there was great criticism of wharfies earning as much as $80,000 and up to $100,000 per year for very little effort, the same money is being earned but only if high product rates are maintained. Seventh, and most importantly, the average crane rate is 26 containers lifted per hour. In fact, frequently at the Melbourne docks crane rates have exceeded this figure, with a record 35 container movements per hour being noted. An obvious consequence of this improved container rate is improved ship turnaround times.

This is the success achieved by Patricks and backed by the government in the form of meeting redundancy packages. The Australian wharves are, at this rate, becoming world class. The other major stevedoring operation, P&O Ports, is currently in discussions with the MUA, aiming to achieve similar improvements. Obviously it is taking advantage of the path blazed by Patricks. Nevertheless, the government has indicated to P&O Ports that it will not support any redundancy packages unless its seven stated benchmark reforms are met.

More crucial reform is needed. Given that two major stevedoring companies handle 95 per cent of containerised trade, greater competition in this area needs to be introduced. It would be in the national interest for the government to support new entrants otherwise the major cost savings achieved by the stevedoring companies are unlikely to be passed on, at least in full, to the customer.

talk.start.para: —Hear, hear!

—After all, savings to our exporters has always been the main motivation behind the government's involving itself in waterfront reform. It is why the NFF also became involved. As a National Party senator—my colleague Senator O'Chee is also in the chamber—I am only too keen to see some of these savings go straight to the farm gate. The greater profit margin that would be achieved by farmers from these reforms going to the farm gate would have a cascading effect on their local region. There are several means by which a government may support the entry of a major player or support an existing operation. However, we need a three- or even four-pillar policy on our wharves to bring to fruition our intent to bring the wharves to the level of world's best practice.

—I rise this evening, one of the closing days of parliament for 1998, to take the opportunity of saying a few words about the nation's capital, Canberra. Even though Canberra obviously is my home, as the elected representative in this place along with the President, Senator Reid, I watch with interest the range of attitudes expressed by federal parliamentarians about this city. I suppose I find myself this evening bemused with a number of pieces of correspondence I have received over the last few days; they, more than anything else, highlight the damage that has been done to Canberra under a coalition government.

speech.para: This issue is a difficult one to raise, because here in opposition we are forever accused of talking down the Canberra economy, talking down what this place has to offer. But, contrary to that, our advocacy fought on behalf of the people of Canberra is aimed at bringing to the attention of the government the structural damage it has done to this place through both its changes in approach to the public sector and the ignorance with which it approaches the relationship between the public and private sectors in the regional economy.

These two issues, more than anything else, come to the fore in the campaign that has been embarked upon—a campaign being waged in conjunction with the ACT government and, I know, supported by the federal government. Letters have been distributed to federal members of parliament; the new minister for territories responsible for this city is writing to me as a local resident—and I presume to every other federal parliamentarian—asking me to take a closer look at Canberra and what a wonderful place it is.

Obviously I do not have a lot of time to spend on this issue tonight, as time is nearly out. But the point I want to make is: why letters? They do not come in place of decisive action and the reversing of some of the harsher impacts of the cuts to the public sector and the unanalysed effects they have had on our private sector.

We know that pressures on charities in this town have increased, and we know that jobs have declined. We know that job security is under threat, and we know that thousands of families have run away. So my message to the government is this: deal not with this issue through mere letters, but take stock of the substance of your policies.
